We also got a picnic lunch, which you order from the front desk, to take to Forrest Park. It was a little pricey for what we got, but definitely worth the experience. I believe it was around $25-$30 for a plate of meat, cheese, crackers, grapes, and two water bottles. All packaged in a checkered picnic basket, and a blanket was provided as well. As for the hotel room, the bed was very comfortable and noise was never an issue for us. We didn't get to try the pool, as it was too cool outside. The staff was super friendly. I had actually planned a return visit, during which we were going to take our dog (they have Royal Pet program where they provide treats, food bowls, a bed, and a bunch of other freebies) but had to give to someone else because something came up. We can't wait to go back (and hopefully try one of the themed rooms!).BF and I had a mini stay-cation here during Loufest, and It was wonderful in every way. You can't beat the central location in the heart of St Louis close to major roads, landmarks, and amenities. It is beyond boutique and well on the way to charming and distinctive. We were given a comp upgrade to a junior suite, the Lord Byron Room. A charming, comfortable space with an amazingly huge, soft bed and clean, modern bathroom. There is poetry and historical art on the walls, so over the top it's funny and kitschy. I had to steal the "Do Not Disturb" to take home for my own bedroom door as it reads "Do Not Even Consider Knocking Unless you are the Queen Herself" on it....it was just paper, but sorry Cheshire! Complimentary breakfast buffet in the morning is simple but nice. Good coffees, teas, and a variety of juices and milks to drink. To eat there is plenty of quality fresh fruit, cereal, pastries, bagels, yogurt, and hot breakfast sandwiches, even after the buffet was technically over. Lots of late sleepers after Loufest, I suppose! I do wish that they had a shuttle as we were just headed to the park, but a cab was under $10. We thought about taking the cute, old school bicycles available to use free of charge, but I did not think that I was going to be able to make my way back after a long day at the fest...We spent one day at their outdoor pool. It's a smaller space, but well maintained with the perfect temperature water, beautiful landscaping, and attentive waitstaff for food and drink. We hired a dog sitter, but I noticed that the hotel is dog friendly and many patrons take advantage of that- though all of the dogs I saw were very well behaved. It really felt like we were out of town for a few days and we did not want out time to end. We will be back!Summertime is here!!!! Thank you, Thank you, Thank you Cheshire for making my first summer back in MO one to look forward too! This has become my favorite new place to sip and sun poolside....along with my girlfriend and friends. The poolside service is extremely attentive, my drinks never run dry and thankfully, neither do I!!!! I was thankful to find a pool in STL that offered bar service and the best surprise was no day pass fee!!! I would recommend it to anyone but I fear once the secret's out, it will get too crowded;)I travel a lot....Most weeks of the year for work. And unlike the previous post I will take Hilton. While I think they have a unique concept ---- housekeeping really lacks. I walked in and it was hard to tell that they made the bed ---- it was that bad. Rather than lining the trashcans they hung the bags over the cans, really do you think I am going to line them ---- I think not. Then the dirty sock in the room ---- YUCK! The parking situation needs some work too. But the people at the front desk last night were quite friendly and the fitness center is one of the best I have seen, thus 2 stars rather than 1 star. Poor housekeeping in a hotel doesn't sit well with me.What a great hotel experience. Fantastic charm in the lobby; you feel like you've stepped back in time. I set up my "office" on an overstuffed leather couch in front of a massive fireplace and got lots of work done. Baroque music plays softly in the background. Lovely old English style that's surprisingly not obnoxious at all. My room was clean and modern; they renovated not long ago. Great access to Saint Louis.I am only reviewing the bar/restaurant for the Cheshire, I didn't stay in any rooms so I can't comment on that. The newly renovated hotel and bar/lounge/pool were REALLY nice. Watch out for the old bear in the lobby.We came in on a cool fall evening to enjoy some appetizers and drinks and ended up staying for dinner! We tried just about everything on the small menu. The wings were excellent - big and juicy with very good seasoning and sauce. The house frites came with an excellent aoili (I'm a sucker for a good aoili) and were fried to perfection. For dinner, I had the pulled chicken sandwich - which als was a pleasant suprise. I really liked the barbeque sauce they used. They had a nice draft beer selection and the bar was really rustic feeling.We sat outside in the courtyard and even though no one else was there they were kind enough to get a nice little fire started in the firepit. This is a great little Best Kept Secret, but I have a feeling it won't be for long. Can't wait to go back and hang out in the bar and sip some scotch.Absolutely LOVED this place! It's a little bit of England in suburban St. Louis, right down to the KEEP LEFT traffic pattern in the underground garage. The rooms are gorgeous, the service is impeccable, and it's very dog friendly.Awesome! Our dog was a welcome guest too. Very clean and comfortable, beautiful stained glass windows, fun decor and a delicious breakfast! I wrote all about it here - wp.me/p1cn3Q-sdThis hotel is the best! It's clean, comfortable, in a great location and fun! The room themes were really cool and nicely done. My husband and I stopped in for a night on our way cross country. We were upgraded to a huge suite with a large jacuzzi tub and king bed. The bed was so comfortable, I didn't want to get up in the morning! I did though, and was served an awesome complimentary buffet breakfast with tons of fresh fruit, bagels, pastries and breakfast burritos. A great start to our day!The staff was so helpful and pleasant and the hotel even accepted our little dog! Not only would we stay here again, but I really wouldn't want to stay anywhere else in St. Louis! The tavern was really great too!I just stayed here this past weekend. Service was excellent, rooms were great and the renovation is gorgeous. The Fox and the Hound was a great spot to have after dinner drinks. Will definitely be back.My nephew was getting married, I booked a room for 2 nights 4 months ago. Parking options were expensive, I grabbed a spot open in the hotel owned restaurant lot next door. I immediately noticed the filthy glass in the front doors and the sticky, tacky feel of the handles and door. On the way to the slow, noisy and extremely hot elevator I was stunned to see that apparently a packed warehouse of heavy, ponderous 'olde' English furniture, artwork and knick knacks had thrown up in every square inch of space. The murky lighting and heavy dark woodwork created an utterly exhausting energy drain. I was stunned to discover my room hadn't been cleaned. There were used towels thrown over the ice bucket and in the bathroom. There was a spray bottle of cleaner left behind that obviously hadn't been used. The glass covering the tops of the furniture was filmy, smeared, greasy feeling and extremely dusty. The coffeemaker was covered with dust and large, greasy fingerprints. The floor was covered with dirty footprints and the carpet tacks sticking up from the line where carpet met floor was a painful touch. I was stuck several times. The sheets had not been changed and one of the pillows had the strong stench of dead fish. The heavy wood bed frame had whitish streaks, dribbles and smears. There was no soap, shampoo etc. There was hair all over the bathroom. I went back into the hellishly hot elevator and spoke to the desk person. It was after 9 p.m., I had just driven 7 hours and the thought of finding a different place in a strange city was not appealing. The desk person said he would send up a housekeeper immediately, apologized and comped half the rate for the night. A young man knocked on the door with a stack of towels. I asked him what that was about. He said he had no idea. I explained the situation, he came in and immediately commented that the room hadn't been cleaned in a long time and needed some serious detail cleaning. He told me there are no housekeeping people at night. He went to the front desk with me to confirm the condition of the room and the price was comped 100%. I refused to sleep on used sheets so this young man helped me change the bed. His eyes fell on the large spots and stains the same time mine did. Our eyes met as he asked, I wonder what that is? I said, oh, you know exactly what that is! We changed all the linen, he suggested I do not touch the throw. It gets worse! The air conditioning rattled constantly. And for some insane reason, probably the same reasoning behind the hideous decor and giant stuffed bear in the lobby, claws reaching out in warning to run, run! the bathroom lights, all 4 of them, are on a motion sensor with NO WAY TO TURN THEM OFF! Walk by, on they go, go in, on they go, go in at 3 a.m. and on they go, glaring, blaring light bouncing off the mirror and glass shower door, ensuring that you are now wide awake and can listen to the rattling AC the rest of the night. The next morning I had to attend the wedding rehearsal without a shower or even washing my face. I assumed that the desk person would make sure cleaning services were provided first thing in the morning. Nope. My room was not cleaned and supplied until 4:30 in the afternoon, 1 hour before I had to go to the rehearsal dinner. After the room was cleaned the glass remained smeared, the coffeemaker untouched, the ice bucket still had it's nice thick insulating layer of dust and the desk chair had little bits and pieces of something red, hard candy maybe, and pieces of cellophane. The lamps remained dusty and smeary. The shower is set in such a way that you have to get in to turn it on, no way to reach in and adjust the temperature before entering. And those lights! My God! I could have operated on myself. When I returned that evening other wedding attendees had arrived to discover their rooms in the same condition as mine. Several employees were in the hall trying to make peace. I snagged one to unscrew the lightbulbs in the bathroom asking him what the hell was going on with motion sensors in a hotel room bathroom. He laughed and said it was the owner's idea. I learned that several visitors for the wedding were furious and ready to check out except, as it was with me, they had come long distances and were utterly exhausted. On the very scant plus side- the mattress was very comfortable, the down pillows and comforter good quality. Complimentary breakfast was good, fresh fruit, sliced turkey and cheese, a variety of muffins, bagels and sweet rolls, bean roll ups, juices, tea and coffee. No one to replenish plates, coffee or wipe the eating areas. Guests had to go to the front desk to request items. Every guest for the wedding had a horrible experience. I was comped the full visit as were others. This place is disgustingly dirty, sticky, noisy and not worth even half the nightly rate.We stayed here a couple of weeks ago and had a great time. One of the biggest standouts for me was the staff - everyone we met was very friendly and helpful and had an obvious pride in the hotel and its related ventures (they'd just opened The Restaurant two weeks previously and two more restaurants are in the works). It's very English country-style, with lots of heavy carved furniture and animal trophies, hunt paintings on the wall. Each room is named after an English author and you'll find a book or two by that author in your room. I'm not sure all the rooms are suites, but ours was and it was very spacious. I believe everything was recently remodeled - it was definitely clean and well-maintained, with a contemporary-style bathroom (shower only). I'd definitely stay here again.Overall a very nice experience. I loved the charm of the hotel and the old English design. I was in town for the St. Louis Scottish Games. The games recommended the hotel on their website (among another option or two) and the hotel reciprocated with a promotional rate of $129/night (plus tax). I was given room 245, a "superior king room." The room was nicely appointed but did face a rather busy road. For some this may have been a problem, but I can live with traffic noise, and didn't mind especially as I got the special rate. In the hotel's defense I was emailed an upgrade option after booking (at minimal cost) which I elected to skip. There were a few minor items with the room...a bedside light which didn't work, a motion activated bathroom light which couldn't be manually controlled, and a sink stopper that wouldn't stay shut. The check-in was easy and the staff were polite. Parking came at a cost, which I avoided by parking behind the restaurant. I would stay here again.After stumbling on this hotel through "name you own price" on Priceline, I was initially pleasantly surprised. Newly renovated, old English quaint, great location. Since I knew it would appeal to my wife, I flew her in from Charlotte for a couple of days.The 2nd night we ate in the Pub there. Later that evening, I got very, very ill. Food poisoning. After a really rough night, I requested to extend my stay for a day because I was very ill and could barely get out of bed. First we were told there were no rooms and we must vacate by 11am (even though I had to previously request room make-up because it hadn't been touched when I returned at 4:30 the previous day). After further complaining about my condition, they offered to "allow" me stay for $229 a night but I would have to move to another room. I protested having to move as we were already in a small room and I was too weak but they said "take it or leave it". They never inquired as to the severity of my illness, offered to call a doctor, nor showed any compassion at all. Moreover, the front desk attitude was verging on snotty and inexplicably unconcerned about the food poisoning from their Pub restaurant. Since I had to move rooms anyway, I called the Marriott hotline, explained my condition, and they found me a nearby room I could immediately occupy. They even had a small basket of OTC stomach and pain medications waiting when I checked-in. As far as I am concerned, the Cheshire staff I dealt with was the antithesis of hospitality. Beware. Finally, the bathroom had two of its three lights burned-out and the fact that the automatic bathroom light control does not have a manual overide is absolutely absurd.The service at The Cheshire was truly excellent and the newly remodeled rooms were clean, comfortable and well appointed. I was a little leery when I looked at the pictures on line because of the "themey" feel, but in fact, the hotel is tasteful, has character and the rooms are on par, or slightly nicer, than a Westin.

review_content: I stayed here this week after I attended the Braggin' Rights game at the Scottrade Center.I booked my room on Priceline by using the Name Your Own Price option and got a great deal. Because of this, I felt comfortable valeting my car for $26. Normally this wouldn't be the case! There are several lots and garages in the area which might be cheaper.All of the staff I encountered were beyond friendly. My room was spacious though the furnishings are a bit outdated. This really didn't matter to me though because everything was clean!The Omni Majestic is a quick walk to some great restaurants (Bridge Tap House and Baileys' Range). They also offer a shuttle within a 3 mile radius of the hotel. I didn't use this amenity because everywhere I went was close by. I think this is a great place to be if you are in downtown St. Louis.We chose this hotel because of its proximity to the Scottrade Center since we were in town for the ACDC concert.  I made a reservations for 2 rooms.  We arrived at 3:00, the hotels preferred check in time.  One room was ready, one was not.  We were told it would be at least another hour before our second room would be available.  We decided to make the best of it and hang out in the bar.  The bartender was great!  As we waited patiently for 4:00, we noticed that everyone else was being told it would be at least an hour before their room was ready.  Needless to say, a lot of unhappy campers in the hotel!   I took the elevator down to the basement to use the restroom.  The banquet rooms are also in the basement and this is where the employees of the hotel could be found having a baby shower.  Our second room wasn't available until 4:15.  There were many folks still waiting for their rooms when we left for dinner at 5:15.  The air conditioning did not work in either of our rooms.  My call to the front desk did not produce results.  I was told the engineer could come take a look but it would be several hours. Our room rate included one free breakfast.  We did not eat breakfast but my husband did go downstairs to get us two cups of coffee for which he was charged $6. We will not return to this hotel.This hotel is a GREAT value for what it offers. It's located within walking distance of many of downtown St. Louis' attractions, it's clean, archtechurally interesting, the staff is friendly and accommodating and maybe best of all...it's not cookie-cutter. The rooms are spacious and appointed with more traditional groupings than you see in most "modern" hotels. And most importantly to a woman, the bathroom was spacious with proper countertop space.We stayed on a Saturday evening (10/31/15) for the anniversary of our first date. We wanted to stay downtown since we were dining at Kemoll's for dinner and didn't want to make the long drive home afterwards. We selected the Omni based on three things: location, a "shuttle" available and the price. We'd read reviews and felt it would likely be clean as that's a pet peeve of mine. Much to my delight, I did find it to be clean and the "shuttle" is a beautiful black Escalade, so let's go!Our stay was brief, but pleasant. The doorman (and holder of the keys to the Escalade) was Emrah. He was a DELIGHT and knows how to greet guests and certainly does far more multi-tasking than I'm used to from a doorman. We've stayed in downtown Manhattan and didn't experience the kind of customer service we got from Emrah. This man is definitely the person you want making the first impression of your hotel. He's neatly dressed, articulate, friendly but deferential, and manages to answer questions, open doors, smile, handle luggage...and apparently take you to and from dinner! That was such a special touch on our anniversary. I hate stinky cabs with rude drivers, so having this door to door service with Emrah was such a delight! Well done, Omni Management. And...give that man a raise because he's the best advertisement you have. And no, I'm not related to him. :)Our only complaint, and this is super picky for the price we paid, is that there are only a few vending machines (not on each floor), but I was able to find a cold soda from a nice gentleman behind the bar in the restaurant downstairs. Although they weren't open at the time, he still accommodated me. Problem solved!We will go back!Big fan of the people of the Omni Majestic. We stayed there this past weekend. The staff was bar none, the absolute best hotel staff I've ever had the pleasure of staying with. The front desk, the cleaning crew, everyone was top notch! With that said, keep in mind this isn't a 5 star luxury hotel. It's just a place to park your bottom.The only complaint I have was being put on the corner of the second floor. Right outside of our window was two giant street lights... Not usually a problem, but the dark curtains do not close, so we only had sheer curtains to block out what I consider 'sunlight' from these lamps.. Easily fixed by installing dark curtains.Trip Adviser sir LIED!I predict: this place SHUT DOWN SOON! 1 room was flooded so they "upgraded" us to a room w/ sheets so thin and w/ holes I was sleeping on the uncovered mattress. Went looking for ice... Opened a maids closet on the 5th floor that had a stack of what looked like BLOODY pillows inside. Creepy! The Walsh are thin. Elevators like mahogany lined coffins for 2.It's like a flop house not a modern hotel.Beautiful, wonderful people and hotel. Upon our arrival we were informed that our room was not available - not a problem though as they placed our items out of eye while we ventured out to watch Sunday football for a few hours. Once we returned the on-duty attendant informed us we'd been upgraded to a suite [no reason given, but it was quite appreciated]. While I got to nap in the suite, the manager [I believe] opened up the restaurant for the guys to continue watching football. Shuttle service was amazing in of itself - they'll pick up/drop off anywhere within 3 miles of the hotel until 945p. For a small city this encompasses much of the attractions/sight-seeing things. When we had to wait to leave, it was no more than 10 minutes. It was a little disappointing though to have to wait at the Candy Kitchen for 30 minutes. Simply put, one of the best hotel experiences ever for me.DO NOT BOOK A GROUP RESERVATION HERE!I wanted to have my wedding party and guest stay at this beautiful hotel located on a few miles from our reception. I looked into group rates, with their group sales department, but found their web rate to be cheaper than their group rate. Therefore, I called to notify the group sales office that we were going to book our reservations without the group block. BUT, they told me to wait because they could get a group block rate that was more affordable than the current web rate. Five hours later, I received an email offer with group rates that were still higher than the previous viewed web rate. I went back online to simply make our own reservations and low and behold the web rates had increased $20-60/night. Frustrated, I called the manager and explained that I had held off on making my reservations because group sales stated they could offer a more affordable group rate. The manager stated he could not honor that previous web rate or offer for a more affordable group rate. Unfortunately, this hotel's customer service does not match the hotel's aesthetics. I will never consider an omni hotel again after experiencing such dishonest and poor customer service. I hope informing others of my experience will prevent other groups and bridal parties from such disappointment.Not really all that great for the money we spent, have to pay for parking per day as well as no complimentary breakfast, also really old and out datedAmazing value for the money. It depends on demand for the day you visit, as some weekend hotels downtown start at $200 for budget hotels, but this Friday we were able to get a king bed at the Omni Majestic via Priceline bidding for $56. $56! One of the cheapest hotels I've stayed at, yet much nicer than others I've paid $200+ for. Highly recommended.The staff working here is the absolute best. Alisha (sp) and another girl working were so amazing and accommodating. I simply don't think I would have gotten the same help anywhere else in the city. THANK YOU!Stayed in room 908, bathroom fan not working, found headboard post broke off and crudely wood glued back together. It added a nice low class motel touch.  Found litter on the floor (cocktail straw) when we got in, so attention to detail is lacking. They will tell you they offer vallet for $26/day, yet if you walk across the street you can get the car parked for $8 a night. The rooms are spacious,booked a last minute deal and got it for under $75. This hotel is not worth a penny more.Stayed at the Omni last night with a large group who had got a block of rooms for a wedding. We checked into our room around 2am after the wedding.  A couple hours after we fell asleep we were abruptly awoken by a fire alarm in our room at 6am.  This alarm had a woman's voice with it who just kept saying that they were inspecting to determine if there was a threat or not.  We stayed in our rooms while this annoying alarm went off for an hour.  It ended up being a false alarm. Upon check out they offered us no apologies or explanations for the alarm that brought us wide awake in the middle of our sleep. As we sat in the lobby waiting for our ride. The groom and some of our other friends came down to the lobby.  The groom complained about the alarm and the hotel gave him $50 off of his room.  I asked him about it and he told me they were discounting $50 to ppl for the inconvenience  of the alarm.  I walked over to the two ladies at the front and asked if we were eligible for the same discount they just gave to my friend.   The ladies response to me (keep in mind 30 seconds after she discounted my friend).  "What discount?"    I said the one you just gave my friend standing 20 feet away. They told me they only discounted two rooms in our party and it was for people who were "really inconvenienced" by the alarm that went off in our room from 6-7am.  But we could go get some free breakfast.  We had already made plans with friend to go to brunch so we passed.  But they should have led with that offering not used it as leverage after we complain.  Also lying or playing dumb about a discount you just gave my friend is a pretty poor business practice. As a small business owner.  I always worry about the customers who experience bad service and just don't want to make a big deal about it.   You lose those customers future business without even realizing they will never give you a second chance. I've stayed at the Omni in Dallas,San Diego, and my home town St Louis.  I won't be back.  They clearly don't care about their guests experience or retention.I stayed here for a wedding recently, and it's a fine hotel. I don't often (this is the first time) stay in downtown St. Louis, so I can't really compare rates (especially since this was for a wedding block) or compare to other nearby properties, but this was nice enough.They don't have much of a lobby - it's not obvious when you walk in where you need to go check in. It's just a very unassuming desk right where you enter the hotel. So that's odd, but doesn't really matter. My room was large and comfortable, beds were nice (although, no fitted sheets, tsk tsk) and the shower had pretty solid water pressure. Everything I needed.A couple rooms weren't ready (I checked in with a number of other wedding-goers) and in compensation, a very helpful gentleman opened the bar for us and comped multiple drinks for multiple people, including those whose rooms *were* ready. So I thought that was very nice. He even gave us recommendations for nearby restaurants, even though the hotel did serve food. So not just trying to make money for himself.I also had breakfast the next morning, and while it was a nice little spread, it was on the high side for what I'd prefer to pay. But, downtown, captive audience, etc, I can forgive them for that.Would I stay again? Sure. I'm not in hotels in the area often (since I have family nearby) but if I needed a hotel in downtown St. Louis, I would definitely consider this. Plus they have a loyalty arrangement with some hotel group that includes the First Hotel I stayed at in Copenhagen...where I would have made their top tier in a single stay. If only I would have signed up...BED BUGS! BED BUGS! BED BUGS! I slept with bed bugs last night and added a couple of photos of one of the superstars. Please check your bedding when staying here.They were super nice about it and the general manager is paying to have our clothing laundered. But be aware!!Staff was rude! Place is beyond outdated. I had hair in my food. And seemed done intentional. Only goid thing was parking seemed easy. Food was clearly gross. I now stay at Magnolia hotel. Its newer and amazing for the same price or cheaper. I will never stay here again!!I travel everywhere throughout the U.S.  I've been what are proclaimed as "the best". I must say, I found "the best" here in the Omni in Saint Louis. Upon checkin we were greeted by a lady at the front entrance. She was VERY accommodating. She addressed me by my last name the entire trip checking in on us throughout. She saw that we had kids so she immediately asked if we needed sheets for them. I said yes. By the time my wife got to the room there was a knock at the door with someone with sheets in hand. Service is what sets hotels apart and this group nailed it 100%. Great job!!!  We will be back!!!!Great Hotel! The staff are extremely friendly and super helpful. Rooms are a nice size, not too big, not too small, but just right. Beds are extremely comfortable. The only thing missing is a pool, but they have a fitness center, and other nice amenities. It was also great having a nice shuttle to get you places within a 3 mile radius in case you don't feel like walking. I would definitely stay again when I return to St.Louis.I've never experienced anything as unbelievable as to what happened at this hotel.  I travel regularly as the owner of two companies and this was my first time staying at an Omni Hotel.  After a long week of travel, my partner met me to see the gateway arch and explore the city museum, two local attractions.When we got back to our room that night, we were in shock.   Our room, 208, was directly above the bar that had music louder than a dance club.  This was at 11:30 at night.  We decided to relax thinking they certainly could not go past midnight.  They did.  I called the front desk and they did not answer, probably because they knew why I was calling.  I called again and the staff member picked up...you could hear the music clear as day though the handset.  I asked her when the music would be shut down as we needed to sleep (It was now 12:05 AM), she told us they were going until 1:00.  I asked if there was anything they could do as we were very tired, like move us to a different room, and she said no...but she would leave a note for the manager.  We continued to listen to music that was conversation level in our room with lyrics that were derogatory to African Americans and the LGBT community and a song about something called truffle butter that comes from lady parts.  We were both in shock that the hotel would allow such explicit music to be played in an open lobby area at 12:30 at night - especially when it could be heard clearly on the 2nd floor.  It left us wide awake wondering what they meant by things like truffle butter - quite disturbing as we are a gay couple.Finally at 12:50 they shut down the music, and our room became peaceful - we had no other complaints about the room besides the fact that we could not sleep until 1:00 AM.We were taken aback when in the morning they slipped the hotel bill under our door without even an acknowledgement of what had happened overnight.  Surely I thought to myself that the manager at the front desk was ready to rectify the situation.  When I went to check out he said the total and told us to have a good day.  I told him that we had a terrible night in the room (208) and told him a note was left for the manager to discuss with us in the morning.  He told us he was the manager and wasn't aware.  We explained what happened and he told us they would take off our parking for the night.  That seemed like a pittance given that from 10 PM on most hotels will enforce a noise ordnance and throw guests out that do not comply.  Our only option was to lay awake in our bed and listen to the disgusting lyrics in our room, some of which were highly offensive to a gay couple.  I told him I would not have paid anything for the room or stayed at the hotel had I known this would have been our experience and he said, "I'm sorry for the inconvenience." We left infuriated at the situation and how poor customer service is at the Omni Majestic Hotel and that they felt free parking justifies keeping guests up until 1:00 AM without any prior notice.  Certainly we will never be staying in this hotel again, and it brings into question the Omni brand being that this was our first experience.Awesome!!! This hotel was well worth the price. Perfectly located in the downtown area (for tourist purposes) walking distance from all major attraction! The staff is super friendly and helpful! And they have a "shuttle" which is more like a personal car service.  At no cost they will take you on a first come first serve basis to any location within 3 miles!!!!! The room was spacious and clean towels were amazingly soft (lost of fabric softener :)) the pillows were perfect and the bed was super comfy!I must say I was a little weary keeping my reservation after reading previous reviews. That being said, I'm glad I didn't. I was in town for the Blackhawks game a couple weeks ago. The staff was incredibly friendly and helpful. We were promptly checked in to our room. The room was incredibly clean and bed was so soft. I will always consider staying at the Omni for future visits.
review_content_20: I only gave this hotel 1 star because one of the managers tried to redeem themselves after the fact.This hotel blows some serious chunks. I stayed here in late July for 4 nights for a wedding that I was in. I see a lot of reviews that keep stating that there are nice perks here, and you get a complimentary beverage in the morning. The juices they offer are store bought, not organic or freshly squeezed or anything. Even the grapefruit juice is some RubyRed juice by OceanSpray in a glass. Also, be warned that the pictures on the internet do not show you a true picture of this hotel. It is old, not modern in the least bit, certainly not even close to the standard of other Omni locations. They have an office desk as the registration/check-in area. It's absurdity at its finest. Everyone that walks in for the first time always walks past the front desk because it's not standard for a concierge style desk to be the registration area at a hotel. Upon arrival (around 11am) I was told that rooms are not ready and check-in is at 3pm...although I requested an early check-in with my reservation. I explained to the staff member that we flew in from CA, approximately 2000 miles away on a red-eye flight...we were BEYOND exhausted. I was basically told to leave and they'll call me when my room is ready, so I grabbed a bite to eat, toured the city a bit in my rental, and proceeded back to the hotel. Hours passed by at this point, and I just knew that the staff had not made me a priority to get checked-in. When I returned they behaved mildly concerned about getting me a room...even radioed the housekeeping staff to "double-check" if my room was ready. This room had been ready for some time. These staff members are slow, nothing is urgent to them and they seem to have a careless attitude about everything...with an exception of the night staff, which is all very accommodating. An hour before we were to arrive at the wedding, the water in our room stopped running. We called the front desk to notify them, and they said they'd send someone from maintenance to fix the issue. 30 minutes later the water was back on with no explanation as to what happened, and as a result of this delay I barely made my friend's wedding! The next day before I checked out I talked with the front desk staff to give them feedback on my experience. I told them that I've never stayed at a hotel that's lost water, certainly not an Omni hotel, and I've stayed at hundreds of hotels. The staff member of course looked at me with a blank stare, mostly like they didn't care about me being annoyed with the quality of my stay. She then told me the manager was on lunch, so she would wait to finalize my bill so that the manager can make adjustments to the bill for my inconvenience. Several days went by, and I actually never received a follow-up phone call or an electronic receipt as I requested, so I decided to call them. The same staff member I dealt with answered, and I recapped my entire experience with her. After all of that she told me "I remember you and no the manager did not take anything off of your bill". Great...so I then asked for the number to their corporate office. The staff member then asked me to hold. Which I did for about 5 minutes and finally I was in touch with a manager on duty. They asked if they could help me, so I told her my story, my issues with my stay, and how I was annoyed because no one had even apologized to me for not having running water in my hotel room! It was only after getting angry that I was able to convince these folks to do the right thing and discount SOMETHING off of my bill. Candidly speaking, my opinion is that the management and staff here are pretty rude and careless until you've threaten to call corporate on them for the awful service they've provided you. Stay here if you don't like running water in your hotel room, and overpriced valet parking that's in a lot uncovered next door.So pleasantly surprised by this charming hotel in DT St. Louis. It's centrally located, and walking distance from the Arch, Scott Trade Center, and Bush stadium. Like many other reviewers have commented on, the staff at this hotel is truly amazing. They're exceptionally friendly at all hours and will go out of their way to make you feel welcome. They truly go over and above! Yes this place can seem a little antiquated but I enjoyed the quirkiness of it, and most importantly it was comfortable after a long day of walking. I don't know the next time I'll be back in StL, but I will definitely be coming back to this place when I do.Stayed at the Omni for one night recently while visiting some friends in the city. The service was good when we first arrived. Very friendly staff helped me get my bags up to my room and aided me in finding some good places in the area for some food and drinks. The room was nice, but there were some issues that made the night less than enjoyable. The faucet in the bathtub dripped several times per minute, making a loud noise echo through the room. Despite my best efforts to stop the noise, I called the desk to have someone sent up while I was out to dinner. When I came back, the drip persisted, with no sign of it being touched. I ended up just using earplugs to sleep through the night. The bed was very comfortable and the pillows felt like heaven on my neck. The lighting was pitch black at night, which made for some good z's. If the bathtub hadn't ruined the ambiance, this hotel would have been great.Do not stay here.  Room was dirty and the lost the keys for my valet car for over an hour.  On top of that, they did not reimburse for the locksmith I had to call.  I stay on the road in many different hotels and this is by far the worst.  Stay away.I booked this hotel room through a military website, of which I purchased the reservation through a military credit card. While the booking process was seemless, the follow through and the check in process at this hotel wasn't so spectacular. On the latter portion of my stay, my friend joined me as I was a seminary related function at Pride. She was mostly impressed with the hotel. However, I was a tad disappointed, as the hotel's accomodations did not meet the $200 per night price tag and other high charges. So, I ordered a double bed room for two nights. When I walked into the place, I noticed the size of the lobby. The check in desk was also a simple desk with an agent behind the desk. When I got my room, I was shocked. I definitely did not get what I originally ordered: a double bedroom. I was given a single bed room with a king size bed. The room was a bit smaller than what I was advised and the bathroom was even smaller. The TV was a small box TV tube set, not nicer flat screen TVs. Omni definitely needs to look into at least upgrading to plasma flat screens, since most $50 chain hotels offer that service.The bed was nice and fluffy and I was seriously considering stealing the linen. However, that was the only plus that I could think of. Other amenities? A gym? No, don't think about that. There was a small gym downstairs, but that place was almost in disrepair. There is no pool. There is no gift shop, but they gave us walking directions to a shnuck's drugstore to get any needed supplies. The complimentary shuttle service seemed to have driven off to space. Oh yeah, their $25 valet service involved getting the desk person to walk out to the car and drive it up to the hotel. And they store the car in a parking lot where normal people can park and pay $12 a day. Other outrageous charges and surcharges involved a $10 per night 3 meg internet service (not complimentary), and their hotel dining lounge, which offers a $12 breakfast buffet, which offered a small buffet that only sat on two tables. I seriously think that Omni needs to visit RiverCity or Lumeire and check out what a real buffet encompasses. The rooms didn't even have smaller mini fridges or the hallways did not have any ice machines. The only positive aspect of this hotel would be the nicer and enthusiastic customer service and the plush beds. However, that could not save the fact that this was extremly overpriced and the bedroom suites were overly eggagerated as "suites".Honestly, I recommend that you save your money, pay half, and go to a nicer hotel (eg. Doubletree or the Hilton). Skip this joint.Aside from the very friendly and efficient front desk staff (really it's a front table) and clean room, this hotel leaves some things to be desired.  First thing I would desire would be hot water that does more than come and go. Add to that a shower that takes a moment to figure out how to get the sem-hot water going - turn the knob to the right, towards the C?  Add to that a shower that barely dribbles when you pull to stem on the faucet to get the shower going.  You get the picture.... Morning wake up time was not too fun.  In room WiFi was fast though so, give them one more plus I suppose.We stayed at this hotel for five nights in the first week of June. Everything was excellent especially the service that we received from each and every person who works at this property. Everyone always had a smile on their face at any time you saw them. Rooms were super clean and comfortable. Having the shuttle that takes you anywhere in a 3 mile radius was nice too. Only thing I would prefer would be a pool, but they told me they are apart of something like the historical hotels association which doesn't let them have one. Not a deal breaker to me. Hopefully the next time week go back to STL they will have all rooms with HDTV's!Stop searching and stay here. This hotel had impeccable service, beautiful rooms, and amenities that surpass many hotels I've been in before. The interior (especially the room) looks like an old, historic NYC hotel. You are offered to join their guest club for free the day you arrive. This allows for unlimited in room internet service, free pressing, and 2 beverages in the morning by your door. They offer a shuttle service to all the major surrounding attractions. There is a bar in the hotel that also has food. It's everything you need! Enjoy your soft, luxurious robe and sleep until checkout in pitch darkness and quiet. This hotel will do anything to make your stay worth every dollar. A few tips: park on the street and get a ticket for $10; it's cheaper than valet. It's also right across from the entrance! My only complaint was the bartender at the hotel. He was nice, but after leaving a cash tip on the table and going to the bar to pay, he kept staring at me to leave him a tip. It was awkward and made me want to go back and get the tip I left! No one else in the hotel was like that, though. I will stay there again! I just won't visit the bar.Perfectly priced hotel with amazing customer service.If staying downtown, I would recommend the Omni.  If you are traveling with a dog, stay at the Omni.   They gave our little guy a bag of treats and a new toy, so sweet.  Every time he entered the lobby, he was met with 'oohs' and "awws", sounds you feel your best little guy deserves, but is nice to hear from a staff of employees that don't have to do that.  Someone was always opening the doors and saying a warm hello.  When room service was not available, someone was more than happy to hand deliver  menus of local restaurants that were willing to deliver.  The place is tradition in decor, but modern in their approach.  The rooms are comfortable and clean, not current and pristine.  It's a boutique hotel with slow elevators, but charm and service overshadow any shortcomings.This was our first stay at the Omni Majestic.  It is within walking distance of any of the great architectural sites and they have a free shuttle that takes you within a three mile radius.The staff was outstanding in their hospitality.  Rooms were very clean and well maintained.  While we had a great corner view of the Civil Courts and Southern Bell buildings, this is not a place for the views but rather for the comforts.  The hotel restaurant was ok.  We had a good breakfast, I cannot speak for the other foods but never did it seem busy.  There are lots of places for the younger crowd over on Washington Street.  Make sure to join their rewards program which entitles you to complimentary WiFi and morning in room beverage.The price point was on the spot.  A great value compared to its competitors closer to the Arch and so much quieter away from the raucous sports fans and noisy tourists.It will be our primary choice of lodging when visiting this city.This is by far one of the most positive experiences I have had at a hotel. The staff here are top-notch. They made us feel comfortable the minute we arrived. To give you an example, the front desk staff (I feel really bad I did not catch your name) called me by Mr. (mylastname) the entire time I was there. They asked me several times if I was enjoying my stay. When I first arrived I did not like my room because it was adjoining and I could hear my neighbors; they had a new room for me within a few minutes. They had chocolate dipped strawberries and champagne on Thursday evening. That was nice.  Oh! And they have a shuttle that will take, and pick you up, within a 3 mile radius. Doesn't get better than that. Highly recommend this place.This was my first stay and it was very excellent. Nice staff, nice room, great location.They really went above and beyond and exceeded my expectations. On my last day of the stay I happened to get really, really sick. I checked out, went to the office that I was working from, and they asked if I could just go back to the hotel (good idea.) I was worried because I had already checked out.Not only did they let me get back into my room until my flight later that day, they were SO helpful and got me anything and everything I needed. Multiple boxes of kleenexes, lots of hot water for tea. The soup of the day was chili (which wouldn't be too soothing) and they made special creamy vegetable soup instead. SO NICE!I will be back. Thank you!I didn't stay at The Omni today, but I was definitely treated like I did.My daughter, husband and I spent the afternoon walking and playing at Citygarden. We were there longer than we planned and I noticed that my diabetic husband was experiencing low blood sugar. We started walking in hopes of finding someplace to get him some sugar. We spotted The Omni and walked into the lobby asking for a Coke as quickly as possible.The gentlemen in the lobby were outstanding. They got him a Coke...then another. They told us to have a seat and take as long as we needed. Then he went off to get a banana. We stayed in the lobby for about 15 minutes and felt right at home.Running a hotel should include being a part of the community. I will always remember how these men welcomed us and helped us. When I have friends and family in town, I will certainly speak highly of The Omni.Thank you so much.I should have listened to the previous reviews. The two stars are for the comfort of the bed. That was the only plus about this place. "Tired and old" is definitely a good description of what you'll find at this establishment. We were let down from the beginning. There isn't even enough room in the lobby for a check-in counter, so you sit at a tiny desk fit for one person in order to check in. Awkward and unwelcoming. The gym is tiny, shoved in a small basement room with an eerie feel. I think there were maybe three machines down there. They also have no vending machines (c'mon, even the Motel six has that?), so you're forced into the hotel "restaurant", which looks abandoned, and has poor decor and terrible lighting. Oh, I guess you do have the option of drinking the $5 bottle of water in the room. The room is poorly designed, with a tiny bathroom, and 1988 Zenith-style box TV. No pool or any other amenities at this place. Very bare bones. Oh, and it needs a revamp. The elevator had stains all over the door and paint and wallpaper were peeling in places around the room. And if you're staying downtown with kids, don't take them here. Not family-friendly. Your kids will be bored.  I feel like I got ripped off for $160/night. I would've been better off anywhere else.Great hotel.  Very clean, and friendly staff.   They provide a shuttle that will basically take you anywhere you want to go, and the driver was very knowledgeable about the area and gave many great suggestions.I came here with my friend to stay on saturday night for pridefest. While I am a local to the city, we decided to stay close to pride so that we could fully enjoy the weekend without having to drive back to where we live. The hotel itself is very clean and the employees were always asking if we needing anything to make out stay better, but i can say that they did an excellent job in providing service weather they could get it or they directed us to where we could get what we needed. I do have to say that the bar there has an excellent breakfast (i believe it's only open on the weekends, but i may be wrong here) and stay open till 11pm for drinks, if you need one. The rooms were clean, spacious and the beds comfortable (I'm very picky and seem to only get good nights rests at my home... I know picky!) and the pillows wonderful!We recently stayed at the Omni Majestic St Louis and the staff was amazing!  They found out it was my daughter's birthday and sent a piece of chocolate cake up to our room. Attentive does not begin to describe the service we were given. Thank you to everyone there.This was a lovely hotel.  The rooms were exactly how they are displayed on their website and the staff is equally friendly.  The only draw back was that their air conditioning was non-existant during our stay. My co-workers and I were in St. Louis for a training session and this hotel was conveniently located across the street from our corporate office. They did have a very nice breakfast layout but we were all complaining about the lack of cool air blowing in our rooms.  We were told that it wasn't warm enough for them to get the air conditioning going but it was fairly warm during the days we spent there.Overall, the rooms are great, the elevator is a bit small but does the job and the staff is what made our stay more pleasant. Super attentive, hospitable and positive.Omni Majestic Hotel is a little boutique hotel with an amazing little bar bathed in windows all around it. Prices are hotel prices so don't get excited about affordability. Don't go to a hotel bar if you are a budget. But Omni has enough character and charm with its warm woods and low lighting to make it worth the investment. Wine selections is decent. The house chard was very drinkable. Beer selection isn't Growlers but you should be able to find most domestics and imports that have good distribution. Although I don't think PBR is on the menu.There is street parking in front or valet for $5. Very reasonable. Omni promotes itself as a family friendly environment so if you have out-of-town guests with kids, Omni is a great choice for lodging.After reading its many great reviews and anxious to take advantage of my newly-raised status with Omni's Select Guest program, I booked two nights at the Omni Majestic in St. Louis, Missouri. The hotel's glowing reviews seem to share a common theme: the friendly, customer-service oriented staff with whom so many guests are impressed. My contact with the hotel's staff was neither good nor bad - the staff conducted themselves professionally and were attentive to my needs. This should be of no surprise - how else would we expect them to be? A smiling, enthusiastic front desk agent does not make a hotel three star versus four star, though.The Omni Majestic is located on Pine Street in downtown St. Louis. It is the lone hotel in this part of town, as nearly all of the other luxury hotels are found close to the Arch. On the weekend, downtown is a ghost town - there are no stores in walking distance that are open and the choice of restaurants is limited as well. If you arrive by plane and do not rent a car, you will find yourself trapped. From the airport, I took the MetroLink directly to downtown. It cost just $3.75 and took about thirty-five minutes. The Omni is about a block and a half from the 8th & Pine station. Approaching the hotel, it's exterior is drab and uninspiring. It did not have an "old" look as much as it had a Orwellian 1984 look. The hotel's entrance is unimpressive as is the lobby, despite the grand piano that looks out of place. The front desk is literally just that - a desk at the door where someone is seated, waiting to check you in. I assumed the front desk was being renovated but no, this was the front desk. The front desk agents were friendly. I requested my room upgrade but was told that the hotel was completely booked and there was nothing available. I was given keys to a room on the sixth floor. My room was a huge disappointment. The decor is uninspired, boring and lacks any charm. The windows provided a view of nothing. The television was old - no flat screen, and there was no safe in the room for valuables. Perhaps worst of all was the bathroom, for which even "small" would be an overstatement. I assume this hotel has nicer rooms wherein some of these things have been addressed. It is, therefore, an even greater disappointment that the hotel provided this room to one of its most loyal guests. The internet service was okay at best. The fitness center should be closed. It had two or three very old cardio machines and two sets (a total of four) dumbbells laid on the floor. What a joke. I have seen two-star hotel gyms with more variety. Aside from that, the fitness center is in the basement and lacks any decor to brighten it up or inspire. There was no turn-down service in the evening. I thought about giving room service a try just after 10:00 p.m., only to learn that it was already closed for the evening. This hotel could have old-world, historic charm, but instead it just looks neglected and dated. It lacks a four-star feel but charges four-star rates, excessive considering the hotel's offerings. Similarly priced hotels are located by the Arch, a much better area, offering views, modern amenities and up-to-date technology. I love Omni hotels, but the Majestic is a huge disappointment.
review_content_40: I stayed 3 nights at the Omni Majestic for a business trip.  I frequent the Omni chain and just recently obtained Platinum status in their loyalty program.  That meant this trip I would receive a local market item in my room as well as bottled water refreshed nightly.  When I arrived to my room, the welcome card was addressed to Mr. Bryan, clearly not my name.  I also did not have my amenity, which was a bowl of nuts.  I called to the front desk to be sure I was in the right room.  The gentleman was courteous but really didn't seem to care about getting me a card with my name or my "welcome" treats, as a Platinum member. I also received bottled water on one night only.  This was the trend the remaining time I was there.  The staff was courteous enough, but really didn't go out of their way like other Omni hotels. Two times when I ordered room service they did not bring silverware and one morning they forgot my complimentary beverage, another supposed perk of being a loyalty program member.  The resteraunt in the hotel was so-so at best.  The food was usually cool when delivered and there was not much variety.  Certainly disappointing experience, even though I do frequent Omni chains, I will not stay here when I come to St. Louis again.The Omni Majestic is truly a three-star boutique hotel, but the excellent service my mom and I received while staying here bumps this place up a star.We both had been flying from opposite ends of the country (me since the night before) in order to attend my grandmother's wake and burial. The funeral home was close to the Omni Majestic, and from the reviews I chose it as our home-base while we were in St. Louis.I had phoned prior to our arrival to let them know we were coming. When we arrived Mark and someone else who's name I cannot remember (but she was the sweetest woman ever) greeted us. We were early, but they got us into a room quickly. They stored our bags while we got some food in our stomachs and off we went upstairs.The hotel is rather dated. The elevator is old and the smell is not that great. It still smells like it's legal to smoke indoors-that's how long it's been since the carpet was changed out-or perhaps it was never changed out.The room was nice. Bathrooms are tiny and the televisions are the old tubes. They also offer complimentary shuttle service within 5 miles.The $25 a night parking fee is a bit steep considering the location and city. I'd expect that in Chicago, Miami or NYC, but not a boutique hotel in St. Louis. If you want nice, centrally located, clean-though dated and great service I'd recommend the Omni Majestic for your stay. If you want big and roomy with some glamour, keep looking.All in all, such a pleasant and positive stay. They were very kind and accommodating during such a difficult time.My first stay at an Omni was in Richmond, VA.  I really enjoyed my stay there, so I was really excited to stay in another one.  The lobby was really nice.  I remember reading that this was a historic hotel.  It had a stately look about it.  There was lemon and lime flavored water, newspapers, tourist information, and oranges in a bowl to welcome guests.  Customer Service:  The hotel staff was seated at a desk and there was only one person there to check in guests, but we didn't have to wait long to be checked in. The staff was very helpful and knowledgeable about the area.  On our last day, we used the shuttle service to go to Budweiser.  The lady who took us, not sure of her name, was really nice and give us some tips about things to do when we returned.  When she came back and picked us up, she took us around to see the best view of the Arch.  She even got out of the car, crossed the street and took pictures for me.  She was awesome!  The restaurant staff in the morning were really polite and helpful.  The older guy especially was engaging with the guests and had a great sense of humor.  Overall, they are fantastic!The room:  As someone else mentioned, it is a historic hotel.  It isn't really modern, but has stately and well appointed furnishings in the room.  I wish there were more electric outlets, but again, it is an older hotel.  It was still very comfortable.  The bed was super comfy and I slept like a baby.  The room was very spacious and the furniture was arranged to maximize the space.  The tv was old, but it had a swivel base.  I do wish that there were more cable channels to watch.  The channels were pretty limited.  The bathroom was nice enough and the room was really clean and smelled good too.  I was greeted by soft music on the tv, a bottle of water, and a hand written note.  It was definitely a nice welcome to the hotel.Convenience:  I didn't drive on this trip, but instead took the Metrolink.  The hotel was very convenient, since it was only a few blocks from the 8th and Pine Street stop.  You can see the Arch from the hotel and it is also within walking distance.  If you don't want to walk, you can take the Metrolink or get the shuttle driver to take you there.  The hotel is right in the downtown area and there are plenty of restaurants a few blocks away and a grocery store, Culinaria (fan-bloody-tastic market), nearby.Amenities:  There is no parking in the front, but there is a lot next to the hotel.  I'm not sure how much it costs.  The breakfast was great!  There were plenty of cereal options, croissants, muffins, cinnamon buns, bagels, sausage, eggs, waffles, and fresh fruit every morning.  There was also orange juice, coffee, tea, cranberry juice and water.  I really liked their gym.  It wasn't too tight in there and they had great Precor equipment.  There was an elliptical, treadmill, stationary bike, and a recumbent bike.  They also had dumbbells, mats, and a basket of towels, Clorox clothes to clean the equipment, and lemon flavored water, although they put too much lemon in it and it was a little bitter.Overall:  Great service, comfortable room, fantastic breakfast, and great location.  I would definitely stay here again and I recommend it to any of you who might be visiting the city.I don't know how Hotwire can call this hotel a 4 star hotel. It's fine if your looking for a 2.5 star hotel. Old rooms, old carpet, big old retro tube TV with a 19" screen and no high definition. The bathroom is tiny and the rooms are cramped. It's really a joke. Few outlets to plug in. Just dated and obsolete. Definitely not a 4 star hotel. Holiday Inns are nicer and cleaner. Take a pass and don't trust Hotwire.This is my second visit to an Omni hotel and both have been perfect. I was in St. Louis for an interview and used Hotwire to get a great rate; when I found out that my $54/night room would be the Omni, I was very pleased. First off, Omni's free-to-join members club is an outright steal; free wifi ($10/day otherwise), free pressing for 2 items, free morning beverages delivered to your room, and free shuttle within 5 miles of the hotel? STEAL. For the Majestic in particular, the staff was extremely courteous (they were welcoming me by name by the next morning) and were nice enough to upgrade my room with no hassles (also free, just ask). So in the end I'm getting a 4 star hotel, with all these freebies for less than $60 a night? Ridiculous. As mentioned by the other reviewers, the location is great and very close to restaurants and a nice supermarket. 2 blocks from the metro. Lots of great bars nearby, including Jack Patricks just a block away. Oh, and their beds and pillows are SUPER comfy as well. Only downside is that their bathrooms can be a little small, but thats minor. Oh, and their in-house "restaurant" isn't really that great in terms of selection/quality, but it makes up for it by being relatively cheap (about $10 for a meal). Can't recommend this hotel and chain enough; I will no doubt keep my eyes peeled for them on hotwire in the future.Excellent service, beautiful wood and brass finishings, rooms are spacious, but the bathrooms are a bit tight. Great location too, walking distance to delicious restaurants, bars, and sights. Can't wait to stay again!Despite a very friendly and polite staff skip this hotel when stating in St. Louis. I have stayed here a few times for business and each time my reservation was screwed up. The rooms are nice but have signs have wear and tear and forget trying to find an outlet you can use. Omni's are nice hotels but this one is old and tired. There are better hotels for the money in the downtown area and they won't charge for a refrigerator to be bought to your room.Stayed for the 1 night I was in St Louis and the staff there was amazing.  They were all super friendly, (thanks for putting up with me laura) the shuttle service (Lincoln navigator) takes you to all the great spots in st Louis. The bartenders were gems. Didn't eat at the restaurant. The only complaint i have is that the pool table slants to the West. This allowed my girlfriend to beat me at pool. That and Jim got me drunk. To keep it a fair review, however, the rooms do need updating. But rest assured that I will be returning.I stayed at this hotel on a business trip to St. Louis this weekend because of all of the positive Yelp reviews, and I'm sorry to say my experience was nowhere near as pleasant as the other reviewers. My main gripe is the value, or lack thereof. Given how the rooms were more than $160 a night, I was surprised that certain basic amenities were missing. There wasn't a fridge in the room, nor were there any vending at all anywhere in the building. When I asked where I could get a can of soda, the woman at the front desk suggested I go four blocks down the street to a grocery store. Meanwhile, the A/C was so clunky it sounded like a death rattle and there were bits of peeling paint and wallpaper in my room. It felt like the Omni forgot to renovate the place whenever it was they took it over.Meanwhile, two mornings in a row I had a problem with wake-up calls. The first time I arranged a wake-up for 6:45am. I ended up waking up around 6:30 anyway because I was on east coast time, then stayed at the hotel for an hour - and the call never came. Then this morning, when I needed to get up around 4am to make a 6am flight, the wake-up call was 10 minutes late. Better than nothing, but I had to scramble like hell to make my cab reservation.The ironic think about all of this is that I had a great night sleep here for three nights in a row. The bed and pillows were very comfortable, well above average, and I woke up feeling well rested. This would easily be a 4-star review if my room hadn't looked so run down and they hadn't screwed up my wake-up calls. Twice.The Omni is where I was shacked up for the impending snow storm that blanketed the area.  I arrived monday at about 4:45pm after falling on the ice not once, but twice less than a block away from the place.  Entering the place was great, an employee opened the interior door for me and welcomed me in.  The lobby is small but nice and very bright with great wood work.  Just past the front desk is the entrance to the restaurant and then the elevators. I decided to head up to see if I could get a quick work out in before my staycation/ business function/ work bender begins. The room was excellent. Nice, large king sized bed with all the trimmings.  The rooms are simple yet elegant and the furnishing are all real wood with a dark finish too them. First thing I do is hop on the wifi to check the weather.  It is $10 for wifi for your stay if you don't get it comp'ed.  Next I decided to turn on the TV to check the local news to see what we were actually in store for.  The remote is, to say the least, worse than my DirecTV remote in that it is unresponsive and a pain to use but after sufficient pressure was applied to the buttons I managed to get it to the channel of my choice and watch as the ice storm overtook the city.  Now I'm feeling lazy, and out of shape so I decide to head on down to the gym to get a little bit of a work out in at least.  The gym is cardio only and they have two different stationary bikes, an elliptical, and a two tread mills (one of which was out of order at the time).  Towels are provided down there along with Yoga mats and they have a TV as well that also sports the same difficult remote as the rooms do.  Time to hit the showers.The shower/bathroom is quite small but efficient enough.  Best part is that I could actually stand underneath the shower head and not have to bend down or anything to wash my hair. I only bring this up because I'm 6'4" and most places have the shower head at like 6' off the ground which makes showering interesting to say the least.  After the rest of my co-workers arrived we spent the evening at the Bar watching the weather come down.  The bartender was excellent and kept us all sufficiently lubricated until closing time before heading to Jack Patricks to close that place down. The next night we ended up actually eating at the restaurant.  The food was ok, nothing to write home about but it was good and was a little higher in price compared to other restaurants in the area but since the storm was still going on we decided to use the expense account once again and grab dinner and some drinks. The restaurant and bar are both beautiful as you can see from some of the photos uploaded by other yelpers.  Breakfast in the morning was ok as well and I really liked how they had Eggs and Sausage on top of the standard bread fare. The coffee is pretty hot also so make sure if you are getting it to-go you grab one of those cardboard holders. I spent 3 nights at the Omni and have to say it was one of the more enjoyable hotel experiences I've had.Let me start by saying I've never met a friendlier staff. They are so polite and accommodating.  Having 6000 sorority women invade your city is no small feat. However, the staff at the Omni act like its nothing new.The hotel, while not brand new, is clean and well maintained. The rooms are large and quite comfortable. My only complaint is the lack of natural sunlight.  The room that we had face the other side of the building. Our room was dark most of the day and the windows did not open.  The hotel is in the middle of downtown and within walking distance of many shops, restaurants and the convention center.  All in all this was a great experience and I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone who plans on visiting the St. Louis Area.Do not recommend! Condition is dated & worn. Rooms show bad signs of being really old. Furniture needs replacement in rooms. Carpet is disgusting. TV is more than 10 yrs old (small screen, boxy type, & buttons busted). Bathroom is poor quality craftsmanship. I even spotted a cockroach scampering. Room is tiny and view is bad. Hotel property is not in a happening area. Restaurant is dead. ...Only plus, reception staff is nice. PS no parking included. Total hassle and extra cost you'll have to budget.We stayed at the Omni on our wedding night after getting married at The Thaxton. The Omni was a beautiful place and convenient for us considering our ceremony/reception site.  Upon arrival we had already been checked in by our day of planner and our car was already parked without problems.  Our room was much more spacious than we expected with a living room area on the side...also not expected. It had two bathrooms which we didn't notice until leaving the next morning.  We had a plate of chocolate covered strawberries with a bottle of champagne. Very exciting for a lady who loves chocolate! The room was neat and tidy and after getting relaxed in we we newlyweds decided to order our breakfast in bed before going to sleep. It promptly arrived at the asked time and was delicious and enough to feed 3 of me. So much food and so worth it! They even had soy milk which is a plus for someone who can't have dairy!We were offered early check in and late check out if needed. We truly enjoyed the room and would recommend and stay again!Outstanding customer service. All the reviews about this property being great were very true. Very comfortable, kid friendly, restaurant in the hotel, right downtown and close to everything.Service at the Omni was exceptional! We stayed here in a mini honeymoon and they went out if their way to accommodate us and sent up complimentary champagne. Bed and pillows were not as comfortable as I like but that could be a difference of opinion. Definitely will stay again.What a cool hotel. Almost boutique but not quite. Room was a little tight with two double beds, but quite, clean and updated.  Restaurant and bar was good as well - when reserving ask for the all inclusive $5 breakfast buffet, well worth it.Nothing but good things to say about this place. I recently was in STL for a concert and had such a great experience while staying at the Omni, my next trip and over night will be here! The staff is so friendly and helpful. The front desk all the way to the restaurant was constant friendliness and willingness to help with anything.My fiance and I stayed here for a little weekend getaway to St. Louis. The staff is amazingly friendly and had good suggestions for dinner. Valet parking is highly recommended since the garages nearby do not have an attendent that stays overnight. The only thing was that the bathroom was small but it wasn't that big of a deal. The bed is heaven...seriously it's amazing. The best sleep EVER! Everything is pretty much in walking distance of all the attractions. Plus there is free Starbucks coffee in the morning :)This is a nice hotel. The rooms are large and comfortable and the beds are just wonderful. The hotel is in a great location (if you want to go around downtown STL) and they offer a free shuttle within 5 miles of the hotel. We used it many times, and the only drawback is that it ends at 10 p.m. The driver recommended a reliable taxi service for us to use instead. The staff at the front desk were incredibly helpful during the day and seemed willing to do almost anything to make our stay even better. When we showed back up at the hotel after checkout (I had dressed for a warmer day and needed a place to change), they were understanding and still friendly, and let us use their restrooms.The night staff was another story. We had purchased the sweetheart/romantic package for the night, which comes with free breakfast, two special drinks, a turndown, etc. When we called down to request our breakfast the night before, the staff member said they'd make a note of it. No breakfast arrived, and we had to go downstairs to get it. Also, when we asked about the drinks/other specials of our package, whoever was at the desk had no idea what we were talking about/what our package even was. Needless to say, we didn't get the two drinks included in our package.Other than the night service issue, our stay at the Omni Majestic was great, and I would recommend it to anyone looking for comfortable, luxury accommodations in St. Louis. We plan on staying at other Omni hotels in the future.We had our wedding reception here in their restaurant area.  They were extremely accommodating and the service was solid, though it was pretty clear that they aren't used to doing this sort of thing.  The only gripe was that there was some miscommunication on the billing, which upped the price-per-person quite significantly, but not enough to totally piss me off. Regardless, everything went as smoothly as it possibly could go.  The food was excellent and they were more than willing to provide tastings and try dishes that were not on the standard menu.  Also, it was definitely one of the cheaper options compared to other venues.
review_content_60: The Omni Majestic is a cute little hotel right in the heart of downtown. Its within walking distance of the arch and other downtown attractions. There was a rib festival two block away when we stayed. The rooms themselves are a little on the small side for an Omni. The TV's are still older tube sets. However the bed was comfy, and the place was clean. The hotel staff was extremely friendly and gave us lots of inside tips on things to do in the St. Louis area.another great weekend at the Omni Majestic.  hint:  ask for an upgrade to one of the suites (presidential OR ambassador)  HUGE, hot tubs, lots of seating, super comfy.  the upgrade will cost you...but still.another thing:  sign up for the FREE select guest programs.  I love this hotel.Downtown is not the best part of St. Louis. Despite the hope of revitalization, it's kind of a ghost town. But downtown is where most people end up staying when they visit, and it's where my friend blocked rooms for her nearby wedding. If you're going to be downtown, the Omni is a great choice. The service here was amazing. Free shuttle service, fantastic free continental breakfast, chocolate mints in your room each night, and a really friendly staff. We left our keys in our room two or three times (it was a total sitcom), and they were great about giving up new keys each time.Now don't get all confused by my pimped out rating. Is this is five star hotel? No, it's not. But do they deserve five stars for being awesome? Yes, they sure do! My mom and I visited this Omni last weekend to see some sights in St. Louis. F'ed up, right? Who visits St. Louis as a tourist? I do, of course! Check in was painless, even with my dog. No stupid waivers to sign. No deposit as it was waived because of a special on their website. All they asked for was my dog's name. Our room was nice, tastefully decorated and comfortable. It was not, however, modern. Comfortable? Yes. Quiet? Yes. Clean? Very. But W style? No.  It was kind of decorated like my the house of my dead step granny. Bless her heart. Her taste in furnishings sucked. The best part about my stay was the wonderful staff. They were SO freaking nice! Just plain nice, efficient and so helpful. I would definitely stay here again.  One tip about parking - there really is no need to valet for $24 a day. Meters are free on Saturdays, Sundays and after 7 or 8 p.m. on weeknights. They are widely available all days of the week. If you're out of the hotel most of the day, it's really a waste to pay that much for parking. Just street park it and feed the meter when necessary.I travel a fair amount for work, and although my trip to St. Louis was for pleasure, I found the Omni Majestic to be much better than many of the big chains I typically stay at (Hyatt, Hilton, Westin, etc). The property itself is a small, historic hotel, giving the place a boutique-like feel. The room was on the large side, and had a comfortable bed, which is always a nice surprise, even in this era of the "Heavenly Bed." But what really threw the Omni into the Yelp 5-star category was the service. From check-in to check-out, the staff went out of their way to make our stay as enjoyable as possible. We got a complimentary shuttle ride over to the Hyatt on Thanksgiving for dinner, and the continental breakfast was probably the yummiest I've ever had at the hotel (definitely try the omelette if you stay here). All in all, a great stay, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone traveling to St. Louis for work or pleasure. Just don't walk the streets after dark -- it's a bit sketchy and desolate --- America's Most Dangerous City!

review_content: We were here with three other couples.  They gave us all rooms next to each other.  The rooms were huge, with each having a separate living area.  There is an enclosed walkway to the casino and free parking.I should have checked here first. That was my first mistake!As I drove to St. Louis, I called to extend my stay an additional night. The person who answered the phone was rude as (bleep) in letting me know that the hotel was booked for the third night that I needed.  Thank God for that. When I arrived, I learned that there is no valet - ok, I'll take that one as my own fault. But who ever heard of a casino hotel with no valet? Huh?The person who checked me in was dry as toast. I arrive in my room after driving 8 hours to find a musty, damp smell waiting for me. It was late so I just went to sleep because I was dead tired.
