I woke up the next morning to find the nastiness posted in the photos.  Some things aren't immediately obvious so I'll list those here. The rest you can see for yourself. I immediately booked a room at a new hotel and checked the (bleep) out of this one.- only 2 can lights in the TINY bathroom. Could barely see when applying my makeup.- the closet only had one door. O_o- the furniture (sofa and chair) was worn and dirty- the vents in the room were bent, dirty, and rattled- the wallpaper had bubbles in it- the carpeting in the roo was worn- the carpeting in the halls is FILTHY. I mean, YUCK.Consider yourself forewarned.Not a business hotel so don't expect it to be. Nice public areas but the hallway and room carpet is filthy and covered with nasty stains. Not in a safe area. I walked once to my office downtown and took cabs after that. Service was actually friendly despite previous reviewsYou can get a nicer room with better customer service for the same price at other hotels in the area. This place is old and run down. The pictures already posted are accurate.This is where you stay when your husband and one of his best friends wants to gamble at the casino, but for any other reason, I would not stay here unless I had to. When we got there, I didn't expect the hotel to look as nice as it did when you saw the exterior of the building. It reminded me of an Embassy Suites with all the rooms facing the main floor. Each room is a suite with bedroom with a separate living area. The best part of the room was the bed. Very comfy. Maybe on any other weekend and any other room i would have had a better time, but it was not meant to be. First off, the carpet had some random red stains by the TV. My husband and I could only guess what it was. The layout of the hotel also made it difficult to sleep because you could hear all the obnoxious drunk people by the bar. There were limited outlets in the room. None around the beds. What hotel does that? It didn't make sense. When we came back late for checkout due to car troubles, our keys didn't work. Understandable since we were late. We went to the front desk and they gave us access to the room. It wasn't until we got to the elevator on the far side of the hotel that we realized that the key still didn't work. I don't think it is that difficult to program a key card. The final straw was when I was taking an afternoon nap. We had left the "do not disturb" sign on the door. The maid decided to come in still. She woke me up. I was sleepy and she had a thick accent so I couldn't understand what she was saying from the living room. Apparently, she wanted me to get up and sign a piece of paper that showed that I declined a room cleaning. I have never had happen at any other hotel before. So rude. Stay away from this hotel if you can. I know that the Four Seasons is pretty expensive and this is probably your only other option, but I would stay away if I could.Last minute decision to go here on the last leg of our trip instead of Louisville, KY. Great choice for sure. Hotel was very reasonable at only $109 (with taxes $148). We asked for an arch view room and ended up in 713. Great view of the arch, downtown and river. Rooms were not just rooms but suites. There was a living room/kitchen area when you first walked in. It had a fold out couch, sink, mini bar, dining table with chairs, another couple of chairs and a flat screen TV. You open the door and the bathroom is to your left. If you keep walking, the bedroom is at the end of the hall. Everything was clean. Staff members were very friendly. Beds were comfortable. Didn't hear a thing from the room next door and it was full of little kids. I was impressed. Short walk across the street to the casino. Highly recommend!Room was nice enough for 3 people to stay. two to share a queen bed and a fold out couch.  bathroom was small.  Plugs are behind the bed mattress and it was heavy to move, however we asked for an extension cord and maintenance quickly brought one and moved bed to plug it in.Don't touch the mini bar--a 12 oz. can of coke is $3. nothing has prices on it--it's a surprise when you check out.The size of the room was nice but it was very run down. The carpets were very dirty both in the halls and in the actual rooms. The sinks were stained. The furniture was so dirty that it made me question whether they were safe to sit on.It was nice that the hotel was attached to the casino but it was quite the trek to get there.I expected much more from a place that looks so nice when you enter.  It used to be an Embassy Suites and the entry still had that appearance.  The desk staff was pleasant bit pushy. Told us to park in their $10 lot. I wish it wasn't so late when we arrived, the free parking is easier access.  Second floor seems to be the party floor. Our room was dirty, and had no working heat.  We spent the night in a 60 degree room because we didn't want to call maintenance for the second time at midnight. The bathroom was dirty, long hairs left in the shower, and the outside of the tub has dirt marks streaming down it. Upon further inspection it appears that the floor of the bathroom had not been well cleaned in quite sometime.  The same goes for the door and the walls, really disgusting. The lighting in the bath is terrible. We asked for a non-smoking room and we were told it would be a $150 charge if we smoked in the room. In the meantime, their burn marks on the carpet as well as other stains, and the toilet and countertops in the bathrooms all have cigarette burns.  Certainly this was a smoking room at one time which they have not updated. Add to all of this housekeeping knocking on the door at 8 AM.  This is very much a sad finish to a great trip.  The rooms themselves, if they had been well cared for would be very nice we had a two queen suite and could've easily had somebody sleep in the living room.Since my last review this hotel has improved significantly. New carpet has been installed on most floors and they are continuing to upgrade themselves. The rooms I've stayed in since then are much better and cleaner. They also have improved the lobby area. Hotel lumiere is on its way up.Booked this hotel for a business trip as rates were the lowest in the city.  It was a great location, there are many bars and restaurants in walking distance.  Being from Chicago I am used to walking everywhere and has no complaints walking anywhere when we stayed here.  Hotel Lumiere is by no means a luxury hotel, but for the price it gets the job done.This isn't a terrible hotel as long as your expectations are low. I went into my stay expecting a nice casino hotel, similar to the Ameristar a few miles away. This is more like what you would find at Chief Snatching Buck's Hotel and Casino. I was told the hotel used to be an Embassy Suites, which explained a lot. Nice fountain, glass elevators, large lobby. All apparently built and last updated in 1972. I was amazed at how dated this property was (see others photos - I didn't look beforehand).I parked in the garage for the casino not knowing any better, and saved myself $20 in the process. This didn't make any sense - covered casino parking is free, but lot parking for the hotel is $20? When waiting to be checked in, the woman at the counter was very abrupt and rude to the customer ahead of me, which was a little shocking because you'd never see that in a Hilton or Hyatt property. In all fairness, this customer did look like she was on meth, but still, the overall attitude displayed screamed "I used to work at the DMV." The room was very very dated and kind of beat up. Nothing functional was broken, but don't expect to impress a date by taking her back here. Bed was comfortable and clean, sitting room was a nice feature, and I only paid $100 for a king suite. Hence the extra star bumping this to a 2. Crowd at the hotel and casino were both pretty ghetto. Again, don't expect to impress a date by bringing her back here, unless she's impressed by Nelly impersonators. The entire floor reeked of weed when I was coming back for the evening. Thats a first for me at a "nicer" hotel. The next morning room service tried to come in at about 9:30am, which wasn't a huge deal but c'mon, checkout is at 11 and I had not checked out yet. No folio under the door as I'd come to expect from other hotels. I've heard the Four Seasons next door is nicer, and it would about have to be. I won't stay at Hotel Lumiere again, but if all you want is a big room near the Landing for $100, this could be your diamond in the rough.I booked this hotel for a 1 night family get away; myself, boyfriend and daughter. We enjoyed the day at the zoo and science museum in St. Louis and due to weather finished with our tourism early and had no problem checking in early. Really, I'm not one to book a lavish lap of luxury on a mini-fam. Trip, but this hotel was better than expected; as I usually try to stick to a lower budget for these sorts of things considering, all my daughter cares about is a pool and all my BF and I care about is a clean soft bed and a shower. This hotel met all expectations and went well above. They have a efficient pool (great for making friends), a nice sauna, jacuzzi and exercise room. Also the hotel is within walking distance to bars and restaurants ( huge advantage, don't pay for parking) also close to the arch and other attractions. The room was clean and well kept, only negative  the mattress on the pull out bed was a bit of a bummer, which the kiddo wasn't too crazy about; but you know what I remember going on road trips with my folks they got the big cozy bed and my sister and I got the springy pullout!! So really it's more of a right of passage lolWe will definitely book this hotel in the future... Grate value for the price!! Very impressed!We stayed at the Lumiere because we decided to see a Rams game at the nearby stadium.First: Book early directly through the hotel and get a significantly better rate on a better room. Don't trust the travel sites that claim it's already booked for your date.  I have to wonder if Lumiere just isn't paying the price to be a preferred hotel, given how hard it was to get a room until I just called them directly. We paid $120 ($105 plus taxes) for a queen suite after all taxes, and that included parking.Beyond that: For the price, this was a good room.  But let me take you through the process, and you can decide just how good it really was...I checked in at the front desk.  She asked me if I needed a parking permit (YES, I did. You can't park in the hotel guest lot without a permit.. they will make you go check in and get your permit).  I asked her, "This is included in my rate, right?"  She looked at me, somewhat condescendingly (I swear she almost rolled her eyes back into the back of her brain) and said, "Ummm if you SAY so..."  Ok. I sure hoped so.  I took the permit and went back to my car to park it.We went to our rooms after parking. The lobby is very nice.  It looked pretty luxurious with the water fall and all the nice tables.  The room was very nice, especially for our advance rate.  The carpets (yes, I saw them mentioned in the reviews) were indeed stained. That wasnt such a big deal. I told my kids not to lie directly on the carpet and to not rub their faces on the carpet.  Really though, I tell them that at ALL hotels... and if you don't, no matter how luxurious and pristine the hotel may seem, you might want to rethink that.  No hotel is truly pristine. But I digress...We were ready to crawl into bed.  The beds were.. a little disturbing.  Both beds had (all white) sheets with visible stains.  I guess the idea of having all-white so that it can be bleached into complete whiteness wasn't working for them. Trying to untuck the sheets and the comforter meant accidentally untucking the sheets all the way down to the mattress. Ooops. And ummm.. eww? First thing I saw was a longish, curly, dark hair on the mattress protector.  Let's just say the length and curliness led me to think maybe this was not a hair from someone's head... You make the conclusions from there... I was kinda grossed out at the question of how thoroughly my bed had been cleaned off between changes.  The setup of sheets above the mattress protector was a flat sheet, a comforter, and another flat sheet.  One can only hope their comforters (which were somewhat duvet-like) are washed between uses... there was no way to sleep in that bed without direct contact with the comforter, which is usually yet another thing I avoid direct skin contact with (I've had friends who did housekeeping in hotels.. They advised me that the comforters are not cleaned between uses and are usually thrown onto the carpets, which are also never really truly cleaned). There was mold on the ceiling in the bathroom.  Not a deal breaker, but... It was also pretty cramped, but I'd not have docked even a single star if that had been all that I'd noted.Now, as far as the rest... If you're going to the Edward Jones Dome for a game, this is a great place to consider.  There's a skywalk over to the casino, and then there's a tunnel from there to directly across the street to the dome.  You can bring your children on this route, as you never need to actually access the gambling areas when cutting through the casino.  There are restaurants that you can also access while cutting through.  The tunnel is a series of moving sidewalks (flat escalators) up to a regular escalator (or elevator) up to street level.Summary:I'd honestly probably have given this hotel a 4 star rating if the sheets hadnt made me a bit apprehensive and made sleeping more difficult the night we stayed.  Nice views, and a very nice setup for much cheaper than any other hotels in walking distance from the dome.Do not stay here. Done - that simple. This place is absolutely disgusting. This doesn't have to do with just my experience, this would be your experience too. You may be fooled by looking at the common areas where it looks somewhat ok but this place is well overpriced and the accommodations are just poor. It is exactly like a motel 6. This is a $59 per night hotel but charges $200 because it is tied to the casino. Everything is smokey and outdated. Service is ghetto. The food is as poor as can be. Trust me on this. Stay anywhere else.For the price I'd never stay here again. The bed was fairly comfy and there was good water pressure but that's about all the nice I can say. Granted the water pressure was good but the water felt slimy, and none of us ever felt clean after the shower. The towels are crap-tastic and don't dry well at all. So you have a slimy water glaze on you and the towel just smears it around, which means you don't feel clean at all. That my friends is called a shower fail. And while we're in the bathroom lets discuss that...why is it so damn tiny? It felt like an airplane toilet with a shower attached to it. Self parking is $10, and prepare to walk your ass off to the hotel lobby. Staff was slow and had that "I don't care" attitude seeping from their pores. And the elevators sometimes go to your floor, sometimes they don't. That sure is a shitty game to play when you're holding all your luggage. The hotel attached to this place is a joke. A complete joke. But that's a review in itself. Anyways, the moral of this review is to look elsewhere. There are other options within a stones throw and we messed up by coming here. Don't make the same mistake.I would give this place only one star, but if you are looking for a conveniently located place for a Rams game or a night at the casino, this works OK.  This is really it's only redeeming quality.  Other than that there are a lot of problems with this place.  Stains.  Stains everywhere.  The carpet everywhere is horrible.  The furniture has stains.  Sheets had stains.  Rooms are big, but the bathrooms are tiny.  Good luck finding a place to plug in your laptop or cell phone.  Every receptacle is behind furniture.  Closet door was completely broken.  Service is not friendly or helpful.  Wifi is free, but pretty weak.  Overall, I would avoid this place in the future, unless you really wanted to stay close to the Edward Jones dome, or if you hate walking outside to get to the casino.  So much potential to be a cool place, but they really miss the mark.As a road warrior I can tell you this hotel is not as bad as some people have said. Yes it needs updating and yes the carpet is dirty. But - I have seen MUCH worse. The staff was fine and I had no issues. The casino reminded me of any I have been in outside of Vegas - yes some are nicer but this was typical. Go visit any Tribal owned casino and it is right there as far as options and atmosphere. I will likely be back when business keeps me downtown - otherwise I stay in the burbs.I stayed at Lumiere for a bachelorette party last weekend.  We all had a fantastic time.The beds were comfortable, the place was clean, and I had a good view of downtown from the 6th floor.  Wins three stars for these attributes.  Wins a star for "wow effect."  That fountain and the glass elevator up... I'm not saying it's the most aesthetically pleasing I've stayed in my life, but it sure is something to admire. The only reason Lumiere Hotel doesn't get five stars is because there was only one tiny trashcan in the room.  With all the drinking happening at Laclede's Landing (in addition to regular trash use), there should be one trashcan in the bathroom, one in the bedroom, and one in the living room area.We were going to walk over to the casino but ran out of time/energy.  I wouldn't mind staying at Lumiere again and rectifying that.Perfectly fine, but from all the hype I expected something a bit nicer. Very nice lobby area. Comfortable bed and suite. No overhead lighting in the bathroom which made for a dim showering experience. Overall we were not terribly impressed.
review_content_20: This hotel was a big let down for me. The first room we received, the door did not close all the way to the bathroom. We requested two beds but only received one. The let out bed had stains on the sheets, very disgusting. The carpet is stained and very dirty. The second room we received, the heat didn't work and the bathroom sink stayed clogged. I suggest that they undergo random inspections. For this to be such a beautiful hotel the upkeep is terrible.If you're ok with Motel 6 at 4 star prices... By all means you'll be ok with this place.  It's old, dingy, not at all what I was expecting for being associated with the Lumiere Casino.  After already paying for our room, I did not care and was ready to leave after being here for an hour.  The pool was dirty, staff was rude.  Yuck.In all fairness.. Room was spacious, and we did get a nice view out onto the lake...  But any hotel I won't let let my kid walk around barefooted...  Well you get the point.I stay in Hotels in excess of 150 nights/year and I feel I'm a fair judge of what makes a hotel exceptional. I can honestly say that this hotel is in the bottom 1% of hotels I've ever stayed in at any price. The fact that we paid $230/night simply adds insult to injury.  The first room we received smelled strongly of smoke, so we requested another room. It smelled better, simply of cleaning products, but the stains on the carpet were pretty discouraging.We tried to relax in the hot tub, but it's cold water was no relief. Also it was difficult to relax with the 27 children playing in the nearby pool. Literally 27 children with no adult supervision. This hotel has an exceptional location with a sky bridge to the nicest casino in STL and a very short walk to the bars and restaurants of the landing. Overall it's a hotel that has enormous potential but was a serious letdown, especially for the price.I'd highly recommend you try any of the other nearby hotels to experience Saint Louis.The most beautiful hotel to be blacklisted...I stayed here for a conference and the hotel lobby and atrium is recently renovated and quite pretty. The hotel food was good. The casino is similar to other mid-priced casinos. When I was looking, gaming tables had $10 minimums. The hotel is attached to the casino and Four Seasons hotel through an indoor walkway.This used to be an Embassy Suites hotel. It is obvious in the layout and the suites still show the same layout and furnishings. The bathroom was very small and poorly lit with only 2 spot lots over the sink and no lighting in the rest of the room. Water pressure and hot water was plentiful.The bed was awful-a broken mattress. My back was aching so badly I slept on the couch. The couch was firm and reasonably comfortable if you can fit on it (I did not open it to a sofa bed). However, I expect a comfortable bed... not an unreasonable request for a hotel. Also, there are no available nor accessible electrical outlets near either desk or bedside. This makes it very hard to work or charge items.The HVAC system was also not operating properly. The thermostat was off by 6-8 degrees and the systems did not change over from AC to heat, despite it being reported to the hotel upon checking into the room. Finally, the Asia restaurant over in the attached casino had decent food, but horrific service with the server ignoring my table of 2 after seating us. The table was dirty and 1/3 of the items were never served.Upon checkout, the hotel tried to overcharge me in excess of my contracted rate. The managers were pleasant enough and wanted to try to help. Once the hotel undergoes a full renovation, I might consider returning; but not until then. Overall, I was VERY disappointed.Worst hotel ever!My husband and I and my parents booked this hotel with suggestions from friends who frequent this hotel once a year for cardinals games. These friends stayed at the hotel this weekend as long as us so that's 4 rooms for 2 nights at $200 a pop not counting tax and fees. All I can say is I can't believe this place cost me over $200 two nights. For starters the HVAC units are garbage in this place. Our first room we walked into was pretty warm so we adjusted the temperature dropped our bags and went for a late lunch. We returned two hours later to the same temp 77. We called the front desk and they had matience bring a tester up to the room to tell us the temp out of the vent was 57 degrees. Well my husband being patient (I'm not) told me to wait it out it will be fine. Within 40 min the desk called to check on the situation, I let them know it had not gotten any better so they asked if we wanted to move rooms. I said yes even though I would have rather stayed on the same floor as our friends and family. So we moved from the second floor to the 8th floor. My husband once again adjusted the temp down to 50 and we all left for dinner. We came back to our room this time about 3 hours later to exact same 77 degrees in the new room. Can you believe this!  So I moved to the couch in my parents room while the desk brought a box fan for my $200 a night room since it wouldn't cool yay me! My parents room was a cool 68. Our other two set of friends rooms were just like our last two rooms 77. So one room out of 5 a decent temp. The next day while leaving for the cardinals game we ran into a family coming into the lobby with two box fans in hand from A STORE! The hotel ran out of fans so they had to buy there OWN THEY WERE SO HOT IN THERE ROOM! Rediculous! This was not the only issue!1. Awful HVAC terribly warm2. Stained carpet terrible in halls and rooms and elevator3. Elevator hardly worked (staff said that was typical)4. Air vents in rooms caked with dust 5. Tile in bathroom was stained and didn't look even moped. 6. Caulk around shower molded and black7. Lobby chairs ripped and leather flaking off. 8. Staff agrees hotel has went down hill in the last couple years. 9. Smelled of stale smoke everywhereIt's my understanding that hotel Lumiere was bought out by embassy suites. Our friends that have frequented this hotel for years and recommended this hotel were embarrassed to tell us to stay there. They said they were mortified how bad it's gotten run down so fast. This hotel needs to get there stuff taken care of and clean and seriously change so many things or they will be closed. When walking out we heard multiple guests complaining at the front desk right along with us. When walking through the casino to our car we actually heard a couple say I can't wait to get out of this hotel from hell. Bottom line people this place is maybe worth $59.00 a night. Don't let there website make you think your staying at the tall hotel and gorgeous Four Seasons. There website completely made me think we were headed to to wrong hotel from the pictures because 90% of the pictures showed THE FOUR SEASONS. Don't give your money to this establishment the only thing this place has going for them is there location. Very disappointed!This place is WAY past its prime. Hallways are a mess with spots & blotches and in passageway between Hotel & Casino, rather smelly. Speaking of the passageway, it is a real ordeal to snake through the corridor, figure out the access/egress codes, walk down staircase, walk up staircase (unless you locate the SLOW Elevator) to finally get to the Casino but WAIT, you are NOT even close to the entrance which is a LONG way down the corridor to your left.Now about the "Suite" we paid through the nose for - it was SMALL and the entry door was pathetic plus you had NO access to the fridge (door must have been welded shut).The Bathroom was so small barely one person could fit in and even then you could barely turn around in it when door closed. Now, WHEN was the last time you stayed in a Hotel (Suite no less) where the bathroom had NO vent??If you look across the street, you will see a 4 Seasons. I HIGHLY  recommend you consider staying there.Extremely Disappointed. We arrived around 11PM. The Front Desk staff was rude.She did not greet us, and I had to ask her if we could check in, which she did after chatting with another employee a little while longer about non work related nonsense. She gave us the wrong room. First our key cards didnt work.  Even though I had reserved and specified a suite with 2 Queens and a pull out bed, she gave us a king bed room. When I requested another room, she gave us a room that I don't think was cleaned. The room smelled like mold and acetone....weird..The towels had stains on them...gross. The fabric on the sofa and carpets was very dirty, with red and brown stains all over. I don't know what happened in that room but it grossed us out. It was so gross that we were going to go to another hotel, but by the time we got that room, it was midnight and we had been driving all day. Overall, extremely disappointed and disgusted. The casino that this was attached to was terrible. We walked in and right back out. I would never return here.I'm giving 5 stars soley for the fact that their beds are AMAZING!!! the service is always great.the rooms are spacious, bathroom is small though. nothing fancy, but always clean.reasonably pricedskywalk to casino!Able to walk to the landing and other STL attractions.I've stayed here multiple times and have never been dissatisfied!The atmosphere of the hotel is very nice. The glass elevators and large lobby are beautiful. The room looked nice when we came in and the beds were comfy. However, this hotel gets a 2/5 for horrible customer service.When we got to the room we realized we had zero garbage cans. I called down and they brought us 2 dinky little tiny garbage cans. There were 6 girls staying in the room so obviously we needed a lot more than that. Then I go into the bathroom and the sink doesn't work. The cold water handle turned all the way around, 360, and the water would not turn off. That night we went to the bars then went back to the casino. My friend and I got in, but when our guy friends tried to get in the one security guard said he had kicked one of them out earlier that day. This never happened. I got the manager to come over and he said my boyfriend's eyes were glossy and they couldn't get in. If anyone out of us was too drunk it was me and my friend who they allowed in. My boyfriend and his friend were perfectly fine, but they could not get in. Fine. So i went to the front desk and complained to the staff there. They were absolutely no help. It was like talking to a brick wall. They told me all they could do was fix the sink and bring me more garbage cans. So this was around 3 am. I was beyond frustrated at this point so I just gave up and went to my room. Then a man came in, mind you this was 3 am, he couldn't wait till the morning? He comes in and walks to the safe. We say what are you doing? He says oh I thought the safe was broke, if it's the sink I'll have to go get my tools and come back. He never came back. We also never got any more garbage cans brought to us. The sheets also had stains on them.Although the hotel was nice and the food was great, the customer service and the staff were horrible and none of our room problems were ever fixed. This hotel left me infuriated and I would not stay there again.This is an old hotel that has been refurbished. It has a nice look, but doesn't appear to be sold out that often. Because of that it seemed they were keeping everyone on the bottom four floors which was disappointing since it would have been cool to have a decent view of the St. Louis Arch or the Mississippi River. *The rooms were very comfortable suites with two TV's, comfortable beds, and a mini fridge that was well stocked. The Moet was reasonably priced as well! That being said, it was so well stocked that the leftovers from Asia, the casino's Asian fusion restaurant, didn't fit. ****The bathrooms were dimly lit, and cramped. It served it's purpose, but made getting ready in the morning a bit difficult. ***Nasty. Rooms, hallways, and elevators are all stained and dirty.   Hotel staff is rude and condescending.  When we complained about the room, they stated no refund once your card was swiped to your room!  Would only give us a different room that was also stained. Spend the extra $10 and stay somewhere nice.Do NOT stay at this dump. This place smelled, water wouldn't drain well in sink and shower, and the carpets throughout the hotel were the most disgusting that we have ever seen.. We paid $200 a night and it is really an $60 a night hotel. I will definitely stay somewhere else next time.We stayed here for two nights complimentary and. Also had some friends from NYC In town. The atmosphere wasn't great. The room was not what I expected. Carpet was dirty. One elevator was out of service and the second elevator was really slow. Since we got complimentary nights it was alright but I wouldn't pay what they charge per night nor probably stay here again.Great location and for the price we paid (through Hotwire) it was great.  We stayed through Christmas, so being attached to a Casino was awesome since nearly everything else was closed.  The room was nice and large, we were loving having multiple rooms.It is an older hotel, but everything was clean and functioning.  The staff was super friendly, even loaning us a deck of cards to play in the lobby bar area before we headed out for the night.  It's great that you can access the Casino and people movers to head into downtown (utilize them, we made the mistake the first night of dodging that crazy intersection).Had fun at the Casino & even won a free buffet breakfast in the morning.We never get housekeeping, unless we are staying for a week or more, so I can't say how well they tidy up daily.  I would not have wanted to pay $200 for this room (I think we got it for around $60) - but I'm guessing it's mostly business/convention people that stay here anyway.Oh, don't forget your keycard to use in the elevator.  That made for interesting times.I spent the weekend at Lumiere Hotel as part of a group of 6 who stayed for 2 nights for free in exchange for social media coverage of everything we did. I can't speak for everyone, but the general consensus was that the hotel was not up to the standards we are used to. I wouldn't recommend the hotel unless you are looking for budget and really want to be attached to the casino/downtown. Pros:- suites - I never get a suite, so the extra space was great. The room has a sitting area with a couch (pull-out), easy chair, TV, table/desk with two chairs and a bar w/fridge. The bedroom itself was a good size with a desk, plenty of space for two suitcases and to move around. - shower - while the bathroom was fine (small but workable), the shower had good water pressure and felt spacious due to a curved shower curtain bar- Atrium style sitting area - I actually like the open railings that overlook the sitting area on the 1st floor. If you've ever been in an Embassy Suites, you'll recognize the layout (this hotel was formerly an ES). - location - if you are looking for a hotel that is attached to a casino or is in the heart of downtown, this could work for you. There is a walkway to the casino so you don't have to step outside to get to the casino, which was appreciated since it was in the high 90s the weekend we were there. You could easily walk to Washington Avenue restaurants/nightlife, Laclede's Landing, Arch, Metro train stations and around downtown.- parking - there are 2 large parking lots for hotel guests plus valet parking. I parked myself. No complaints here. Cons:Where do I start?- old - the hotel simply felt old and worn. Each time you came back from the casino, it strikes you that the hotel feels shabby in comparison. It really hit me when I came back from a spa treatment in the adjacent Four Seasons hotel. - beds - I thought the beds were much too soft, as did my roommate. Some of the other women in our group seemed to like them, so I guess this is just personal preference. I'm also not a fan of feather pillows, though I did get 3 of them for my double bed, I still would have rather had my smashed down pillow at home. - HVAC - The first half of the weekend something must have been broken. The humidity inside the hotel lobby, atrium and halls felt like you were inside an indoor swimming pool. I started sweating the minute I stepped out of our room. They did get it fixed, but it still felt a little muggy inside the hotel. Our room was comfortable, but the 2nd room in our party was too hot and the 3rd room was too cold. - Service - I didn't experience this myself, but one of the room's in our group was a Director's Suite...a HUGE suite with 2 sitting areas plus a large conference/dining table. They had repeated problems from a moldy bathroom, no linens or pillows for the pull out couch and delays in getting things like linens & TP when they called for service. - atrium seating - I took my computer down to the atrium area to sit and work for a bit, and was really disappointed to discover that the tables were too high for the chairs. You sank into the chairs like you were on a couch, but the tables were the height of a dining table. I ended up working at the bar for a few minutes, then quickly decided to go back to my room. - limited wifi - I was really surprised to find out the only place in the hotel with complimentary wifi was in the business center. I really expect to be able to get on the internet for free in my room, but at a minimum I should be able to sit in a lobby or bar area and get on wifi. Not here. - outlets - in today's era, lots of things need to recharge. In a suite, I would expect at least 2 people to have cell phones, laptops and maybe even more things that need to plug in. The only easy access were one each in the bathroom, bar and by the TV. I had to pull the couch out from the wall to sit on the couch and internet surf while plugged in. They could easily fix this by installing a power strip on the desk in the bedroom. - swimming pool - the swimming pool is through a glass wall directly off the atrium area, so I think you would feel like you were on display. It is an indoor pool and is in a fairly small room with no decor. It reminded me of a pool in a fitness center. We decided to pass on swimming even though it was in the high 90s. Just wasn't appealing. - room service breakfast - we ordered room service for our last morning by hanging the order on the door Sat night, and the service was right on time. But, the food was pretty bland. I ordered an English Muffin and hash browns, and the bread was overly crispy but without the little brown edges I expect on something toasted and the potatoes were clearly cooked without any seasoning. Blah. Bottom line...if you will trade amenities and a newer feel for price, then this hotel might just work for you if you can get a good deal. But go with appropriate expectations, or you'll be really disappointed.I'd give this place 5 stars if they updated the carpet in the common areas and somehow got the police to get a handle on the locals that hang out riverfront. The hotel has a huge manned police tower in the parking lot, which tells me they have probably had a lot of trouble with the low life locals that hang down on the riverbank all hours of the night. Went out to my car last night and heard the officer in the tower moving people along, so I was comforted that they are paying attention. I loved the hotel, the towels were the softest I have ever had in a hotel. The bed is super comfy. The walk from the ballpark was quick and nice. The sitting room was awesome to have. The bathrooms are small and poorly lit, but it didn't bother me. I haven't checked out yet, and only just a few minutes ago, we opened the fridge for the first time and saw that there is an empty space in their, I am a little nervous that they may try to charge me for a missing beverage that I didn't consume. So far, the staff has been super nice and helpful. I wish they had something to offer, continental breakfast or something in the hotel, but just like in Vegas, everything is in the casino... Just that this casino isn't on the ground floor, it's across the parking lot. But even a drink vending machine on each floor would have helped. I found my 8th floor, arch view suite to be clean and comfortable. We really enjoyed our stay and would stay here again. My father-in-law had a 1st floor room and loved it too!While I stayed at Hotel Lumiere there was a  lot of construction because of remodeling.  It's great that they are updating their lobby, but I was there to surprise my sister with a bachelorette party so the lobby was underwhelming to welcome her.  The rooms are very nice-the beds were super comfortable.  They do need to update their carpeting in the hallways-it has definitely aged.We checked into our room to find it had not been cleaned from the guests before. We called to ask for a new room or have ours cleaned and never heard back from the front desk. It's an okay place to stay if you don't want to drive after a long night of drinking and gambling, but I would not suggest booking it for a special occasion.I didn't pay a dime because I was there on business, so I can't really comment on the value for the money...but there are plenty of other things to comment on.Pros:Convenience...it's walking distance to all the stadiums and the Arch as well as a number of restaurants and of course the attached Casino.Customer Service...surprisingly good, I was always treated very well and found the staff to be quite friendly. Room size and furnishings are both quite decent with two 40" flat screen TVs (one in the bedroom and one in the sitting area).The bed was pretty comfortable.Cons:Elevators are the worst I've ever encountered in a hotel.  They are slower than death, require key cards to go to all floors except the LL, L and Casino level and I even got stuck in one of them at one point.Because of the bad elevators, I took the stairs...which smell like urine, have a plunger on every floor and do not require a key card...which makes you wonder why you need them for the elevator.Even though the TVs are high quality LG flat screens, they have a terrible cable system with Standard Definition (which made the football games on Sunday unwatchable) and HBO is the only premium channel.The Key Cards were pathetic.  It took at least 3 tries every time you used your key card.The Gym had only one weight machine.Just walking through the Casino makes your clothing smell like an Ash Tray.The internet connection was the worst I've had in years, it was disconnected far more often than it was connected.  The decor is clearly dated and in desperate need of upgrading.I give it three stars because it could be worse, but I'm hesitant to give it 3 instead of 2.Nice room, friendly staff. Maybe if you weren't such a stressed out monster when you were checking in, you would've gotten the upgrade instead of the Illinois view. Every room is pretty nice though.
review_content_40: This is a great value and a very nice Hotel. The staff was very nice cooperative and so very helpful.  The room were very nice older but nice, the lobby was beautiful.  I will plan to stay again when I come through STL.  Only issue, we asked for dinner locations and the front desk suggested the casino restaurants, nice but more costly.  The next day I noticed  down the street there was the Laclede's Landing which had some very cool restaurants, pubs and gift shops.  I would have preferred to go there.This hotel was not worth $200 a night.  I would put it in the $125-$150 range.  Cons: -Our concierge did not know of anything at all to do in downtown St. Louis.  We asked her what there is to do in the area, and she told us to go see the Arch...  However, on the whole the staff was very courteous.-Our shower did not work properly and it filled up with water.  We could not control the temperature of the water, nor shut the water off.  Spinning the water spigot reminded me of spinning the helm on a boat.  It had no beginning and no end.  -The toilet broke during the middle of the night.-The fridge did not work.Pros:-The pool was clean.-The fitness center was above average.The casino and 2d street were pretty un-classy.i stayed here before the remodeling and new name and enjoyed it in 2006.  last year i came back and it had a new name and a million dollar indoor waterfall that comes down several stories of the hotel.  it has an indoor glass walkway that leads next door to the casino which is neat because it keeps it separate if gambling is not your thing.  the staff is very friendly and for the price, you get a clean little suite with new amenities.  the beds and sheets are nice which i always judge a hotel on.

review_content: Stayed there 1/27/16 through 1/28/15. The front desk employees were superb and cordial. Could not have asked for more better staff. We also ran into a maintenance man by the pool and he was very polite and asked how our evening was and if there was anything we needed. The rooms on the 5th and 6th floors have an inner and outer ring setup. We were on the inner ring which made access to the pool and breakfast area very convenient(the inner ring has two entrance/exits into the room). We called to the front desk and she transferred us to the in house restaurant, Sanfilipo's. The service was great, the burger was great and the young woman that delivered our food was very kind. It's amazing how rare and uncommon kindness is in current times, but at this hotel they exceeded expectations.The rooms were very clean and the bed was comfortable. The walls seemed a bit thin but that is nothing to complain about. I recommend this hotel as well as the restaurant. Thank you to the staff!Five stars to the on-site hotel staff! They are simply wonderful and hard-working. Gail and Michael were on different night shifts but equally as amazing! They made sure that our arrival and entry went smoothly. When a mix-up happened with some of our rooms, Gail quickly worked to make things right and was so pleasant in the process. Michael helped me make sure late arriving staff felt well-received after their long travel day. Both are the definition of HOSPITALITY and not just a well-managed hotel. Even the man who brought the rubbish bin to my room was extremely polite!The off-site phone service is not so polite, however, so don't let them turn you away or leave a bad taste in your mouth. They are definitely NOT a good reflection of the on-site hospitality and care.Best hot food and drinks free!! We stayed here for girls weekend and loved the convenience of everything. Hot food at 5:30 to 7. Good drinks, and they were strong too!My friends and I stayed here for two days in mid-May.  I had never stayed at a Drury Inn before.  We arrived around 7:30 in the evening and the woman at the front desk was polite and efficient.  We were able to park next door for free in a parking garage.  I thought that was a fantastic deal to have free parking in a downtown of a major city.  Hotel is next to the home of the St. Louis Rams, a block from a casino, and two blocks from the Landing which has some bars and restaurants.Our room had two queen beds, free wifi, fridge, microwave and two doors-including one into an atrium where the pool, whirlpool, and food area was.  Breakfast was good.  Both days was eggs, potatoes, sausage, biscuits/gravy.  All were on the better side for a free breakfast.  During the evening they have a manager reception which seems nice but I didn't attend.  I did speak with the manager on duty both days who was very friendly.  Room was very clean and a fair size.  We paid 300 + tax for two nights.  Hotel was a 10 minute walk to Busch Stadium. Home of the Cardinals.  The area felt safe to me at all times.I was very impressed with everything about this hotel.  I highly recommend staying here.  Everyone is friendly, everything was clean, and a great value.  Hotel won't /shouldn't be compared with the Ritz but I highly recommend!The hotel was very nice but there were so many things about it that was strange. There was only one set of elevators and no stairs?? Our room had a window to the hall..and when we were trying to go to sleep the light from the hall came in from around the curtain and pretty much lit up the whole room. There were a lot of good things though. They have hot foods and mixed drinks at 5:30 which was nice. I didn't try anything because we had just eaten but it looked good. The breakfast was pretty average. It's really convenient if you're going to the Edward Jones Dome, which we were.A friend invited me to stay with them, they were running the Rock and Roll half marathon. The price was right for the size of the room $110 for a one night stay in downtown St Louis that is within walking distance of so many places to eat and play. The beds were comfy, pillows fluffy and the sheets clean and bug free. The shower head was like standing in the rain, wonderful shower head and for those that forget their shampoo, conditioner or body wash a dispenser was mounted in the shower stall. We did not get to try the complimentary breakfast because we needed to leave before it was served.This hotel has been great from the start. Complimentary wi-if, free services in the business center, and helpful staff everywhere. I certainly would recommend this hotel. I stayed for an ABA conference and after talking amenities with my colleagues, found that not many of the other hotels they stayed in offered breakfast. Ours did!Local.... Decided last minute to stay here on the way home from a long day on the river.Service was EXCELLENT.  The woman that checked us in was super nice and filled us in on all the info as far as where all the amenities are etc.The parking garage is key card access only, and there where plenty of spaces available.  Entrance into the hotel from the garage is key card (at all hours), along with the elevator up to the floors also requires your card.  "After hours" access is also key card only into the front lobby, plus they have security in the lobby.   I am not overly cautious about security, but thought it would be good to note all of the features for anyone worried about staying here downtown.The room was nice and roomy, bed was comfortable.  Bathroom was large, shower was small, but adequate... Maybe could benefit from a curved shower rod to make the shower seem a little roomier.  The room was immaculate.Breakfast was really decent as far as free breakfast goes.  Scrambled eggs, potatoes, sausage and biscuits and gravy... Make your own waffles etc. along with your typical "continental" breakfast items.  I was pleased with the eggs, selection of fruit etc since I don't eat refined carbohydrates.  Breakfast atrium is In The middle of the 5th floor along with the indoor pool.  Hotel rooms are all around the perimeter.  I would think the 5th floor rooms might have the potential to be somewhat noisy for this reason, we stayed on the 6th floor... So I could not really say for sure.  I would probably request a 6th floor room though (6th floor is all non-smoking FYI).All staff was above and beyond nice.  A woman in management stopped to take our plates from out table at breakfast and asked about our stay.  Another gentleman who was cleaning tables also asked us about our stay etc.I would definitely recommend this place to anyone coming in from out of town, or any locals who just want a night out in the town or who are catching a Cards game and just don't want to make the drive home.   If I could give it 10 stars, I would.We stayed at this hotel for 3 nights. Very pleased with the room and the delicious breakfast offered for free. The staff as kind and went out of their way to accommodate our needs. The front desk changed our room from 2 queen beds to 1 king with no hesitation. A gentleman named Segar was very kind and helpful and demonstrated customer service as it should be. Would definitely stay there again!!I've never even heard of Drury Inns, much less stayed at one, but after my first experience here, I'm wishing they would expand beyond Arizona and into California.  This is not a big corporate resort-type facility but is family-owned and I felt like a member of the family, thanks to the staff.  There was free Wi-Fi (are you listening, all you big hotels?), a great complimentary breakfast, and free drinks/hot foods in the evening.  There's even a popcorn machine!  Everyone on the staff that we interacted with, from the front desk to the food service staff to housekeeping, was warm, friendly, and easy to talk with.  I will be checking into the availability of Drury Inns for all my future road trips!Within a spitting distance from the Arch and the Illinois border, this place lives up to the Drury name. Friendly staff, comfortable beds, a computer lab and printing, a Happy Hour with light dinner, and parking garage. Plus the usual like a TV, fridge, microwave, and iron and ironing board. Plenty to do nearby. This is a great location.I stayed here 06/06/14.  My 2 room suite was decent.  The living room had one exterior window, a couch, chair, ottoman, desk, and a TV which sat upon a unit that housed the fridge and microwave. The bedroom also had a TV but no window.  I wasn't wowed by the decor, but everything was clean and comfy.Many of the other rooms are inward facing.  They have "balconies" with a small table and chairs overlooking the "atrium".  The "atrium" is a giant room w/the pool, fitness center, and food area.  It seemed quiet during my stay, but I suspect that during weekends and holidays these rooms could be loud and lack the feeling of privacy.  To avoid this I would request a room with an exterior window.Free parking was a big plus.  I hate to pay for valet only to wait for my car when I want to go explore a new city.  You use your room key to open the garage door.  When you first arrive, you will need to park at the front door to check in and get your key.  The location is convenient.  I walked to the arch and old courthouse.  Busch Stadium is also walkable.  I felt safe walking around alone during the day.Free food and drink is a big plus.  Breakfast was pretty typical, but I had never seen a hotel with free dinner.  Options the night I stayed were: Hot dogs, mac'n cheese, chicken strips, baked potato, salad, ruffled chips, and nachos w/optional chili and cheese.  Adults get 3 free alcoholic beverages.  There were plenty of open tables there, but I chose to take my plate back to the room.I'm pretty content with my stay.  If you are debating staying here, I'd say go for it.It's rated as a 3 star hotel but definitely better than Hilton that we stayed in last night. The TV is bigger and free continental breakfast and between 5pm-7pm hot foods and alcohol drinks. It seems cleaner and nicer bathroom. I want to stay in this hotel every time when I come to St. Louis or another Drury Inn.Stayed here when I attended the Saints/ Rams game this past weekend.VALUE: Saturday night was a bit pricey, but when you throw in free parking, three free drinks at happy hour, free breakfast and happy hour snacks...it works out.PARKING: Easy garage parking that is FREE. Garage is connected to the hotel so you can go from your car right into the hotel without stepping a foot outside.HAPPY HOUR: From about 5:30 to 7:00, you get free food and three free drinks. When I was there, they were serving up some pretty good baked potatoes, Mac n cheese, hot dogs, and chili. Drink selections included some wine, beer, and mixed drinks. Not too bad!BREAKFAST: Served up until 10:00. Bagels, fruit, muffins, scrambled eggs, tator tots, biscuits and gravy.... decent and free!WHAT ELSE IS WITHIN WALKING DISTANCE?: The Arch, The Landing (bar/restaurant district), casinos, parks, the Mississippi, and the Edwards Dome is literally across the street. There are many other hotels nearby too and I am pretty sure that the train stop is right there too.STAFF: Friendly and funnyROOMS: Very clean, pretty quiet, comfortable beds. Shower gel, shampoo, and conditioner were all available in those shower wall dispenser gadgets. No shortage of towels. FINAL VERDICT: I would probably return but would also be open to trying other hotels in the vicinity (for no particular reason).We had a Thanksgiving family reunion and chose Drury Inn because it is centrally located and there are good things to do in St Louis. We stayed 3 days and could not have gone away any happier with our stay. The rooms are comfortable though not luxurious. They are clean and in good repair. The hotel is well appointed with many televisions and lounge areas, meeting rooms available. Parking is attached and included. Breakfast is good. The big surprise is the "kickback" snack which amounts to a free meal and was very welcomed by our large family. Also the staff was extremely friendly and became very familiar to us. I would go back in a minute.The Drury Inn Convention Center is a decenet hotel in a weird area. The hotel itself is excellent, but the area isFREE PARKINGFREE BREAKFASTFREE DRINKS (3 alcholic/non-alcholic drinks!!!)FREE "KICKBACK" (snacks before dinner) but this was more like an actual dinner! While we were there, they had pasta with meatballs, nachos, hotdogs, etc! Plus, our room had 2 doors. One door lead right out to the dining area and pool area! Super awesome, super convenient. The only thing that sucked about our stay was the parking garage was a bit scary to go in and out of...the door closes automatically super fast! I was afraid it would crush us each time we go in and out. Also...the satellite tv sucked. The Giants & Cardinal game kept going in and out! Other than that, everything else made up for it. The hotel is close to the freeway exit and right in the middle of downtown. Arch is not too far away. I would def come back to stay here if I'm ever in the area.Warning: this review contains a RAPTURE reference related to a recent divine action non accompli.  If you're just plain tired of such references to a word that doesn't appear in the Bible, then read no further. But if you know there's something wrong with the world, and that "something wrong" makes you crave justice, read on.We stayed here on a Saturday, and enjoyed almost everything. It's easy to pull up to the curb, and check in was a breeze. Then we drove fifty feet further, turned right, and drove into the garage. Guests park mainly on the fourth level, and use the elevator just inside the secured door. Every exterior door and elevator requires a room key after a certain hour.Once inside, we found our room was standard-sized, not bad, but noticed things like a carpet stain by the desk, some red wax-like spatter on a wall near the floor lamp, and dried coffee on the ironing board leg. We were on the sixth floor, with access to the exterior hallway and the interior balcony that rings the pool, fitness, laundry, and eating areas. This area forms an atrium, with plenty of natural light from above. In the eating area, there were fountain drinks and popcorn, and morning breakfast and evening happy hour are found here. We partook only of the popcorn and soda, having meal reservations at a couple restaurants.In retrospect, perhaps the punch card each guest receives for three drinks should have been a sign of trouble. One free drink -- nice. Two -- generous. But unless you're injured, disabled, or a parent of rug rats, who needs THREE drinks, when in an urban setting surrounded by great bars and restaurants? I'll tell you who: wannabe Frat Boys, who like to gather in the hallways ... and spar w/ one another ... and chase one another at a clomping gallop ... at 2:00 AM ... at 3:00 AM ... as late as 4:00 AM. Long ago, during the era of  "Animal House," I lived in a large dorm, and don't believe anyone was quite that loudly wasted in the hallway by 4:00 AM. When there was partying, we got it out of the way earlier -- we had plenty of things to do the next day, like watch a real football team.  You're thinking that I could have called the front desk, and I suppose you've got a point. But, look, I monitor college students all summer, and this was supposed to be a break.  If I hear someone hurt or dying, I'll do something. Otherwise, I'm just putting in the ear plugs to muffle the commotion a bit.Drury, perhaps you're not technically responsible for every action of your guests. Each day your population is transformed by departures and arrivals.  When there's not a convention, and the Rams/Cards/Blues aren't in town, maybe you really need youngish, young adults to support your revenue stream. Perhaps they were especially excited, celebrating the Rapture's delay. But whether or not Jesus is coming again, these jackasses may be making an unexpected trip to meet him soon. Next time, if there is a next time, I hope that the light at the end of the tunnel is an officer's 20-inch maglite, and that the wicked are tossed out an alley door.The Drury family of hotels I feel is overlooked by a lot of folks.  I am hoping they do some more expansion to reach other cities.  Because I recently (due to a long road trip) had the pleasure of staying at a Drury Inn on more than one occasion.  And we had great experiences.  I had been to a few Drury Inns in my day ; usually because a relative was visiting, & we went to their hotel.  I know I have stayed in a few Drury Inns as well.  But this year, apparently was my year to truly check them out.The hotels are not "fancy" ; at least the ones I have been to thus far.  But I definitely can say that the Drury Inn in Saint Louis (this is only ONE of the lcoations) is definitely a good value.Some PROS:* free parking* free drink tickets + snacks for an evening happy hour* free popcorn & fountain soda available* free breakfast* in walking distance to stuff downtown -- AND very close to the downtown location of my fave STL Pizza joint- Pi PizzeriaThere IS a pool.  However, I never did get to use it because it was monopolized by children the entire time we were there.  But that happens at a lot of places (especially when we stay at the more affordable hotels).  I* The STAFF was super nice* Clean, large room (at least the one we were in)* close to public transportation (as well as the Amtrak station)I would definitely go back & stay at this same hotel.  It pretty much met all of the criteria I have for the price.We came out from Massachusetts this summer for a trip. We was treated great from the time we arrived to the time we left . The rooms where very clean and at a great value. The help at the front desk was amazing .
review_content_20: This place is great! It is just blocks away from many landmarks. We are in St.Louis for the 2014 Midwest haunt convention and  the service was some of the best I have ever revived! All the employees make you their first priority and assisted in helping us anyway possible. With all this hospitality we will be sure to say here again when back in St. Louis.Perfect budget hotel if you need to be close to the convention center.The freebies include: Wifi, parking, Adult drink tickets + snacks for an evening happy hour, popcorn & fountain soda  and a nice  breakfast!The pool is indoors and also has a (small) hot tub. They are currently renovating, but the noise was only during the day.Pros:Parking is greatWiFi is free and it is reliable and super fastGood location downtown although we spent most of our time up by Forest ParkFriendly staffFree breakfast, free soft drinks, free popcorn, free "kickback hour" snacks and alcoholic drinks, although lack of variety and a lack of quality.Reasonable priceCons:Pool is smallBeds are not very comfortableNo variety with the food choicesTowels were not softSoap, shampoo and conditioner were very low grade (bring your own)We stayed at the Drury Inn & Suites near the football stadium while in town for Mardi Gras.  The rooms were clean and nice.  Parking was abundant and free.  The evening free drinks and appetizers were great.  The morning hot breakfast was fantastic.  They are only 2 blocks from the metro stop so public transportation is a breeze.  We'll be back.First and foremost, if you are looking for an upscale hotel, this location isn't for you.  While nice and comfortable, it isn't really high end or modern...The rooms are comfortable.  They are your standard hotel room.  Beds, mini fridge, microwave... One thing I did really like on my last visit is that they have started using dispensers for the shampoo/soap/conditioner rather than having individual bottles.  I don't use the hotel provided stuff anyways, so it seems like a great cost savings for the hotel themselves, as well as environmentally better.The staff has been excellent every time we have stayed here.  Each and every person I've encountered has been pleasant and sociable.The free breakfast is pretty standard to what other places offer.  It is free.. and for that price it works.  It has the waffle makers, donuts, bagels, eggs, etc.  The free drinks and evening appetizers are a nice bonus.  Its nice to have a glass of wine (or two or three) before heading out to dinner for the evening.  Again, the price really solidifies this being a perk.  Free parking... enough said... All in all, I enjoy staying here.  The location is fantastic, walking distance to plenty of things and also the subway around the corner.  An entrance to the casino is across the street and the landing is just a few blocks away as well.Wonderful rooms for a great price! The breakfast was good and the service was outstanding! Free wifi lets you wind down in your room while surfing the web with no charge to you! And you know your car is safe with the free parking garage attached to the building. Overall great hotel. Nightly recommended.As we got closer to our next destination - St. Louis, Missouri, we found a Drury Inn. We called and was able to make reservations quickly. The hotel is located in downtown St. Louis, almost directly across from the arch. Our room did not have a view to the arch, but it was OK. We just needed somewhere to crash for the night. The room was clean but they could've changed some of their paper menus and channel guides in the room.The rate was $130, $15 for parking and no pet fee. Free hot breakfast & wifi.I expected an average stay but was overwhelmed with the hospitalities of Gail and Denise at the front desk. My paperwork and keys were ready even though  I checked in early . The rooms were clean and updated with free Wi-Fi ,secure parking and a great location to see Rams football games. This is a great value with free breakfast and evening hospitality. I look forward to my next stay.Hotel is nice. Beds are comfortable. Staff is super friendly and helpful. MY PROS:1) Free drink tickets during happy hour? Yes please!2) Free appetizers and snacks during happy hour? OK, twist my arm.3) Within walking distance to the arch and hip downtown restaurants? Sa-weet.MY CONS:1) Pool is way too small for the size of the hotel. First evening, we couldn't even get in because 20 kids under 10 were jam-packed in there like sardines.2) Breakfast food is gross. Wish there were some healthy options.Free Parking, Free Breakfast & Dinner, Free T.V. and Free WIFI (That isn't slow!!)  I really enjoyed my stay here. The staff was efficient, nice and very helpful. The decor in the rooms could use some updating but other than that I was pleased.I had a great stay at this Drury Inn last week. I was in StL for a conference at the Renaissance (about 2 blocks away) and didn't want to pay the exorbitant rates for the conference hotel, so I happened upon the Drury.Two things set this Drury apart: value and people. The much-touted "extras" at Drury, especially the daily happy hour, made us the envy of the rest of the conference attendees who were paying $50/night more for their hotel rooms. Those poor folks were also paying $15/day for wi-fi, which was free and easy to use at Drury.But the real clincher here was the people. Every employee I encountered at the Drury was friendly and helpful. This kind of thing really makes a difference to me. Overall, I'd stay at this Drury again in a heartbeat.This is one of the nicest, most convenient hotels to stay at for such a reasonable price.  Everyone here was super friendly, and room was spotless.  We used an arch getaway promo code and received $20 voucher which we used at the arch for the journey to the top.  Free parking (just remember to park in front to check in before entering parking garage) free wifi, free fountain pop & popcorn, free 1 hour of long distance, free kickback munchies which included delicious meatballs, pasta in marinara sauce, hotdogs, and nachos and cheese along with 3 alcoholic beverages a person.  Felt like Christmas in May!  Breakfast tasted much better than rival hotels!  Checkout was at 11 but they let us keep the car in the parking garage until we was done seeing the Arch which was super nice of them. I totally recommend Drury Inn and will always look for them where ever I stay!My wife and I stayed here for two nights on an impromptu Memorial Day Weekend trip to St. Louis.  We had a great time. The rate was affordable, our room was clean, the free dinner/drinks/breakfast were a great bonus, and the location at the convention center was convenient.First, I booked a room on Drury Hotels' website and used the eSaver rate. This is the best rate they offer--better even than the military and government employee rates. If you book with this rate, you have to pay in advance and it is non-refundable, but since we were booking a last-minute trip, this was not a problem for us. With the eSaver rate, we got a room for cheaper than we could have gotten at pretty much any other decent downtown hotel.  Second, our room, while basic, was fairly clean. There were some old, faded stains in the carpet, but the bathroom was clean, the sheets seemed freshly clean, and the room was neat and tidy.Third, the free dinner and drinks, and free breakfast, go so far above and beyond almost every other hotel I've stayed in that I've begun recommending Drury Inns to everyone I know traveling on a budget. The breakfast is basic but thorough--eggs, sausage, biscuits, gravy, some fruit, and a row of waffle makers, coffee, juice.  The dinner is basically ballpark food--always popcorn, and a rotation of chili, baked potatoes, hot dogs, tacos, hamburgers, etc. This might be underwhelming if you paid for it, but is pretty spectacular when you get an endless buffet of it for free.  The best part, however, is the free drinks.  Each guest gets a card redeemable for three free drinks per night.  And they're pretty good drinks, too.  They have some basic light beers, a few different bottles of cheap wine, and even a few mixed drinks--my wife enjoyed the margarita.  The portions aren't too bad, either--maybe a 10 oz. beer, 4 oz. glass of wine. Since we were traveling on a budget, the money we saved enjoying dinner and drinks at the hotel before we headed out for the evening allowed us to enjoy our weekend even more.I keep saying "free" and you might think: "well sure it's 'free,' but you pay for it with the room rate." My wife and I, however, stayed here for around $100 / night. In downtown St. Louis. On a holiday weekend. Booked about 2 days before our trip.  For everything we got, we were tickled at the rate.Overall, this Drury Inn is an incredible bargain right in the middle of St. Louis, a nice walk from the Arch and right across the road from the Rams' stadium.Great location! We stayed here on a cross country trip, so we only had a night to get the feel of St. Louis. This was a great spot to be in. You can walk right out to the arch and the baseball field. We were bummed that there wasn't a home game for us to go to.The room was clean and comfortable and the water pressure was good in the shower. You may want to avoid the 4th floor where we were because there are event rooms on that floor which made them a bit louder and more congested. Also, ask for a room that has a window to the outside and not a window to an inner hallway, and while you're asking try to avoid being too close to the elevators because they beep. This sounds a bit negative, but I would totally stay there again. These are a just a few little things that can be easily avoided when you check in. Happy hour food and three drinks were included which was nice, in addition to a great breakfast spread (considering it was all included)!** Very PET FRIENDLY! No fee to have a small dog in the room with us and nice, accessible, grassy areas around the hotel.The only downside was that it was pretty crowded and felt chaotic in the lobby. And the fee for parking was $15 without valet.After a long day, the beds at the Drury Downtown are "the perfect amount."  You know what I mean.  The hotel is steps away from the arch and a few blocks away from Busch Stadium.  If you are planning a romantic weekend, horse-drawn carriages line up outside across the street.  They have many free amenities such as WiFi, breakfast, and even drinks.  Their service was friendly, and I really liked the fountain and Lewis and Clark statues in the lobby.  As far as I can tell, if you ask for a king size bed, your room will be on the interior of the hotel away from the street noise.This place is like my ex. Pretty on the surface, but once you get to know her, you realize you never stick your ...stick... in crazy.The amenities sound great. Free breakfast and happy hour, free drinks, pop corn, phone calls..the works.The reality? It brings out the entire Ma and Paw family. Breakfast had a 10 minute line just for oily eggs and sausage, happy hour had a 10 minute line, just for oily nachos and hot dogs.The free drinks were from a gun...the same gun that can be used for soda at a bar. They were pumping out swill disguised as alcohol. One "punch" on the card was about 1/4 of a shot.The atrium is nice at first, till you realize two things: 1) You never see outside. 2) The noise is BEYOND annoying. Don't think about sleeping in past 8, it has the buzz of a busy Denny's. Don't think about going to bed before 10, it has an even louder shrill of kids playing in the pool. The sound bounces off the steel roof and all around the place.I am sure there's more, but my fingers hurt. Avoid if you can.Went to St. Louis to see a Rams game when they were playing my Seahawks. I wanted to stay in a hotel that was in walking distance to the Edward Jones Dome but also close enough to other things so my wife and I could do some touristy stuff after the game. This place is directly across the street from the dome and a 10 minute walk from the Arch and so just because of its location I went for it. Little did I know I was getting a lot more for my money then just convenience.The Good things:The Staff: Check-in time is 3:00pm. Driving down from Chicago my wife and I gave ourselves some extra travel time expecting traffic or road construction to hinder our travels but we hit nothing. We soon realized that we were on schedule to arrive in St. Louis before noon. My wife gave the hotel a call while we were still on the road and explained our situation. They told us that they would take care of us and to come in not mattering the time. We arrive, speak to Michael the nice man who my wife talked to earlier, were able to check in, parked in their free parking structure, brought our bags to our room, and I sat on the bed while the clock hit 12:00pm.  Not only saved us money not having to park in a lot with game day prices, but it also gave us a place to change into our Seahawk gear for the big game. Thank you Michael! Other interactions with employees throughout our stay were friendly and helpful but Michael was my favorite. The Room: Nothing life changing but it was nicer than something found at a Motel 6 or Super 8. The room was not huge but spacious enough but more importantly the room was clean and comfortable. The wireless internet was easy to connect to and unlike other hotels in the downtown area it was included with the room. Both the nights we stayed there, despite the low hum of a nearby ice machine, the hotel was quiet and I easily fell asleep in the comfy king sized bed. The Food and Drinks: On the fifth floor there is an open courtyard area where guests can eat breakfast, dinner, and alcoholic drinks all for free. Sure. Like stated in an earlier review, the food is basic and can be considered "ball park" fare, but it's still a nice perk to have especially with the alcoholic drinks being available. Because they close this area at 10pm I did buy a soda from a vending machine later in the evening one night and was pleasantly surprised that the 20oz Pepsi was normally priced at $1.25 and not some bloated price like I'm used to while staying at other hotels.The Security: No. They don't have any armed guards but being downtown I just found it nice that the doors to the hotel and the elevator in the lobby can't be accessed without a hotel key after 10pm. And no. They weren't any stranger dangers lingering about at night, it's actually a pretty quiet downtown and I never felt unsafe, but it was just a nice feeling to know that those who weren't supposed to be in the hotel weren't.The Not So Good Things:Some parts of the building are obviously old and run down a little bit. Nothing too major, except for the back stairwell from the parking garage to the rooms, but the worn out parts are a reminder that this is not any 5 star establishment and can be a damper.Because of all the freebies this is a great place for families. Yes. This is a good thing but if you want some romantic getaway with your loved one then I would avoid this place. This hotel is great for ball games and vacations but there is much to be desired in the sexiness category. I'm not saying romance can't happen here but it's just more difficult with the scent of hot dogs in the air and kids splashing loudly in the hot tub. The Good is Way Better than any sort of Bad:The price is right, the service is right, and my experience with this place will be encouraging me to stay with them again next time I'm in town to see my Seahawks beat up the poor little Rams.After deciding to come to St. Louis for a mini vacation in April, we decided this hotel looked decent, the prices were pretty good for a downtown site with a partial view of the arch, and we figured we'd be pretty close to everything.  We had no problem trying to find the hotel.  Checking in was a breeze as we had reservations.  Parking in the ramp is a little tight, but had no problems there either.  Coming from downtown minneapolis, I wasn't surprised by the $15 fee to park; I was just glad it wasn't $15 a night.  We got a little turned around trying to find our room... that's because the person at the front desk gave us a room number that was non-existent. ha, no big deal. we got our real room, and i was pleasantly surprised!  We did have a "partial view of the arch", which means you get a sliver of the side and you have to lean to look around the building.  BUT the room was HUGE and nicely laid out for the price we paid!  We got a king size bed that was separate from the rest of the room and had it's own flat screen tv.  The "living room" had a little mini bar and fridge and microwave, chairs, table and a couch with another flat screen tv, and then there was the bathroom area that was big enough to move around and the sink was separate from the toilet/shower.  I think we paid around $130 average a night for 3 nights.  Another plus was that they had free breakfast and free snacks/appetizers for dinner, albeit the food wasn't fantastic, but it was edible.  Also, if you are 21 you get 3 free drinks with a punch card.  The drinks are small, so I felt like 3 was pretty fair!  The lobby is pretty and large; there is even a small convenience store located by the front desk (which is a good thing because we drove around for 30 minutes just trying to find a CVS or Walgreens!) The hotel staff was friendly, there was a pool/hot tub/work out room but we didn't use them.  I believe there is also laundry.  Our trip went kind of sour, but I'm glad we had a nice room to come back to at the end of the day.The sign out front says room prices start at $59, which is a lie, but after the shock of finding out what a room REALLY cost, it was a good stay.I was not at the downtown site, but at the I44 & 141 location in St. Louis.   Good breakfast, nice staff, clean room, free long distance and happy hour.This was great, last minute find after many hours on the road.  With a few conventions in town plus a big game, there were only two rooms left and this one was $129.  I feel that this rate was very fair for how clean and quiet our room was.  Very nice front desk staff, secured parking (first time in St. Louis, but it looks like area can be a teensy sketch?  maybe?  places near ballparks seem to be sometimes...), free HOT brekkie, free 60 min of long distance calls per night stay.+++update+++We left a bottle of champagne in the mini fridge.  I called.  The front desk gal told me that "the cleaning staff usually doesn't report likker"    My indignant response of "even champagne?!?!?" got me nowhere, although she wasn't mean or anything.  In fact, her tone was mildly apologetic.  I called back the next day and asked to speak to a manager directly.  I explained the (true) story of just getting married, visiting my brother & sister in law (who recently returned from Iraq) and who had given us this bottle of champagne that they bought when they were on their honeymoon.  Blah, blah, this was a long, sad story, all of it true.  The manager called the cleaning person and found that she hadn't opened it yet!  They sent it back to me in a well-padded (Coach-- guess Drury managers get paid decently) shoebox.  I will love them forever for this.
